I liked the new Star Wars but I wasn't wowed by it. Over-hyping this movie lead me to be a bit disappointed with it.
I left this movie not feeling happy I felt empty I dont know why so many people think this movie is great its better than the prequels but not the originals

I love the original trilogy and I think this Star Wars sucked. I really couldnt enjoy myself because I was constantly thinking how obnoxiously similar it was to the first film without the soul and mystic of the New Hope. I can't believe I am agreeing with George Lucas. This was just a feel good nostalgic movie with no substance or feeling, a 2015 whitewash of the first beautiful film George directed.

This is at best an average Star Wars film. JJ did not add anything new to the universe, he just copied the plot from episode 4. The characters are average, Finn is okay, Kylo Ren loses to an untrained "jedi", and Rey accomplishes everything she wants without any struggle. CLASSIC Disney movie. Its as if you are watching a Marvel remake.

Overrated over hyped worst star wars yet. There was better and more acting in Jar Jar binks than the whole of this movie. If you don't want to think too much and enjoy a 65 action% 15% acting 20% plot then this is for you. This is simply a remake in search for more money. Spoiler alert Nothing original except the new droid which is r2d2 hyped up. C3PO and R2D2 dont appear till near the end of the movie. Wannabe vader 2.0 wannabe emporer 2.0 etc etc nothing original

well crafted, but completely lacking of ideas, the movie recycles original trilogy ideas and trademark without the necessary determination. Plot is weak, characters are two-dimensional, the movie lacks of memorable scenes but is overall well directed and not much boring as the second trilogy.
Reboot the franchise does not justify a complet lack of originality
Kylo Ren in my opinion was the most interesting story, besides Luke, to come from this movie.

Saw the first six within a week just so i could see this and i was OVER THE TOP disappointed with how number 7 panned out. It was boring, it was used, it was all around a snooze. I believe there is maybe 2 lightsaber scenes lasting a total of about 10 minutes out of the entirety of the movie. And i get it.. im huge with dialogue and characters.. THEY NAMED HIM FINN?? FINN??? THATS YOUR NEW MAIN CHARACTER IN STAR WARS?????? FINN????????? if it werent for that little robot i wouldnt of even continued watching

I walked in expecting to be decently satisfied and nostalgic, and I left incredibly disappointed and confused.Completely unremarkable and unquoteable, the movie barely and briefly succeeds in capturing what made the original trilogy great before completely ruining it with a plot full of holes, predictable moments, and questionable backstories with little explanation. I can say that it looks pretty, makes good use of the soundtrack, and shows Daisy Ridley to be a great actress (albeit, a seeming copycat of the other female protagonists of recent action movies. I can't say it's a terrible thing, just predictable).I am most disappointed in the performances of Harrison Ford and Carrie Fisher, showing that their time away from the franchise ruined both their characters and chemistry together on screen (not to mention the poor dialogue choices they were given).Overall, I don't see what people love about this movie. If I closed my eyes to the title screen and forgot it was supposed to be Star Wars, I might have thought it just another lackluster action film. I don't believe it deserves the recognition it has received.

With the exception of Rey and Finn, this was everything I never wanted in a Star Wars film. Filmwise, its story is no where near as engaging as Revenge of the Sith and the visuals have nothing on The Phantom Menace. Minus half a star for being not particularly good fan fiction.

Better than the prequels; however, I felt like this was similar to watching the pilot episode of a television show. This movie seems to be the set-up for the upcoming sequels. It left me with a half-full feeling. A bit more "meat" could have been added to this intensely anticipated movie. Most disappointing was that the familiar characters were a little too self-aware that that were in the previous movies. Corny self-referential lines took me out of the Star Wars reality and more into a wink-wink nod-nod frame of mind. Overall, though, the movie was good. Not great. Good. Here's hoping that SW8 is a fuller movie.
Was good fun to watch but coming away from it and thinking about it, I just can't get over how stupid some of it was.
I found it cartoonish.
Unoriginal re-make of Episode lV (The 1st one)

Unfortunately, I walked out of the film mostly underwhelmed. J.J. Abrams directs the new movie competently enough, but the story they've constructed is nothing more than a recycling of George Lucas' original story. For me, the biggest crime is how wholly unnecessary all of it ends up being.
Beautiful special effect but a very poor copy of A NEW HOPE.A lot of holes in the story.

I think it felt too much like one of the original star Wars films! I mean come on, Talk about lazy writing!cute little droid to make people like it. force sensitive kid on desert planet watched over from afar by old man. death star/bigger death star. trench run take 2. falcon and xwing fly away from blowing up super weapon just before it destroys rebel base. old man killed in front of mentioned force sensitive person which will make said person stronger. stormtrooper here to rescue u. im going to have to stop myself though sadly i can go on. sound familiar?It's basically episode 4 with different character names, and the changed the name of the death star, to Star killer, and made it bigger. AND how could Luke leave his family when he knows how much danger they could be in? On that note, how could Han do the same?Explain how Fin, a young stormtrooper janitor, could even last a second in a Saber battle with Ren?Neither Luke or Anakin excelled that fast.Finally, after waiting 32 years to see what happened to Luke Skywalker, they tell us that we need to wait two years to hear him utter a word?!?! Thats borderline cruelty in my opinion. All in all, epic failure
Unimaginative. Boring. Inconsistent. Forced.

boring. waste of time.Endless chase scenes that seen to have been copied/pasted from the original. Same story retread. No build-up to what was supposed to be the big new development- that ended up being ho-hum. Countless close-ups of characters gritting their teeth.

JJ Abrams has made a movie that looks better the the green screen prequel, but lacks imagination and is full of more plot hole it could be an episode of LOST. Movies have one Job. Put it on the screen. This movies fails at that simple task. Ford being the biggest actor in the film shows he can do the job but his weight hurts the movie as Abrams gives Ford what he's wanted from the beginning. This acted is poorly used and a waste as the poorly case actor that plays Kylo Ren doesn't have the look to connect him to his parentage. His look has me questioning if his mother had a visit from a milkman while his father was out.  The last act which leaves more WTF feelings and questions also robs the very lame Villian his one goal. Be scary. Giving Rey a victory so easly in this movie franchise, was the biggest an most unforgivible mistake. It's robs Kylo Ren of any fear his character might have had before he took of his mask. This is the reason I feel so many don't like his character and feel he is an emo brat, then a super villian.  Over all the movie is a rental and will be remembered as the worst SW movie to date.

Force Awakens is kind of movie which makes you miss James Cameron. The visionary director who actually understands the need and desire of the audience. Force Awaken even lacks the philosophy offered by original movie. It's a product which is made with only one intention, 'Feed the hungry fans and cash the cow'.Starting with the story, it was like watching A New Hope's mesh up with Jurassic World. All elements of the Original movie were present. The Trio of young characters, the good turned bad antagonist and his relationship with the protagonist. Even the death star and some old stars were there. There absolutely is no real goal in the movie. We movie from securing the map to preparing the Jedi to destroying the death star. And story itself has holes big enough to swallow a galaxy which is far far away. It seems that in last 30 years only earth have progressed in technology and biological domain, the galaxy which was so advance 40 years ago, now seems be living the same. Like the original series, antagonists are not killed and neither the family of protagonist is revealed. I wonder if they have any idea about DNA and biology. Also it's not clear that how come antagonist know a lot of technology. From a 30 years old spaceship to a newly built death star. She knows the right circuits to pull out. Characters seemed to be very distant throughout the movie. There absolutely was no chemistry between Han Solo and Princess/General Lea. Who unexpectedly is never mentioned to be from Jedi family. Although after recent success of female protagonist oriented film series, they did pass the torch to a girl.Moving to visual effects and cinematography, perhaps the focus really was to add unnecessary and blunt action sequence. Much like prequels directed by George Lucas, colors were blurred and not so bright. There was no need to watch the movie in Imax or 3d, the worst a director can do to a 3d movie. J J Abrams really lacked a vision here. It is just like watching a 2d film.Acting is okie, Although I did not understand some of the wits. Daisy Ridley is great in her role. She wore the role over and is the best thing in movie crossover. Harrison Ford is good and easy in his role. Carrie Fisher is alright. She did not have much to do that explains more than enough make up even at crucial times. John Boyega and Oscar Isaac played split up of Han Solo's character with not much required jokes.One goes with high expectation but returns very disappointed.
Movie is overall ok but something doesnt work without Darth Vader.

I loved it from the beginning with new characters and possible new futures for them but while going towards the end, the story line starts shaping and its quiet a disappoint due to certain characters not getting their recognition , and for a non fan I am not looking forward for its sequel

No Star Wars feel at all, rather a generic dumb SF with some SW-elements thrown in. Absolutely not worthy of the SW name. Poorly written, badly directed and badly edited. Poor action choreography with way too fast cuts. Jarring camerawork (too close placing, unnecessary movement and "flashy angles") that breaks with the established visual style of the saga, and pulls the audience out of a galaxy far away. Inconsistencies, abandoned characters, unfocused storytelling, unimaginative settings, poor performances. In no logical way a sequel to ROTJ.

Horrible character development, completely implausible situations and a glaring lack of chemistry define this PC reboot of the original Star Wars. We have the Stormtrooper who inexplicably develops a conscience, but no explanation as to why we have Stormtroopers sans Empire. One of our heroes, Poe, is...wait, who is he? We're supposed to care about him...why? And, of course, we have our main hero, a girl who's a junk dealer/ scavenger. At the drop of a hat, she becomes an ace pilot, master mechanic and Bruce Lee Jedi all rolled into one. Then we have our villain, who delivers all the menace and malevolence of Leave it to Beaver's Eddie Haskell while wearing a mask for no reason. Throw in a giant Area 51 alien to replace the Emperor, the First Order to replace the Empire and the Resistance to replace the Rebellion and it's time to search for Luke Skywalker. You see, Luke ran away to hide after one of his Jedi pupils turned out to be a bad boy. In the end, we can only hope that our new hero, Rey, will inform Luke that all this Jedi training is unnecessary in the first place- after all, she had only to pick up a light saber in order to make Darth Maul look like Pee Wee Herman. In the end, this film's only redeeming quality is the opportunity to see Han Solo and Chewbacca on the big screen for the first time in over thirty years, and even this left something to be desired.
Cant understand how this movie has 8,2???

What a complete and utter waste of time and money, and a total erasure of the excitement I had to revisit and enjoy even part of the magic from my childhood experience.Garbage story. Bad character development. A couple of absolutely horrible casting choices and stilted performances. Loaded with clich�s. Entirely derivative from A New Hope - except without any of the charm, mystery, and intrigue. I'm not going to waste time talking about droids with hidden information, hiding under Falcon floor plates, or Death Star channel runs and destruction. It's all far too apparent when you see the film.Want to care about the characters and their stories? Impossible. Even the ones you used to are less than shadows of what they were. Sorry, Harrison, I love you. But aside from a couple of cool moments, Han Solo - one of the most beloved characters of all time - was just completely BLAH. It's an unforgivable insult that this is the drivel that was given to you.Finn. Rey. Poe. Phasma. Ren. Why care about any of them? They are all ridiculously underdeveloped and utterly uninteresting. They are either too perfect (Rey), too pathetic (Finn), disappear and reappear inexplicably and in the most superficial way (Poe), or just not fleshed out whatsoever (Phasma, who really looked cool and could have been built up to something really bad ass - a new Boba Fett. But she was rendered completely insignificant and glossed-over).Kylo Ren. This is our new villain? Seriously? Could he have been any less interesting or weak? He turned out to be nothing more than a tempestuous, troubled teenager. There was no compelling setup or background for his battle with dark and light. He even beared no resemblance to his parents, Han and Leia. And if you want to build any interest over a character with a hidden face and intimidating appearance, you do not unmask him in the first film, let alone have it be that kind of anti-climactic reveal.General Hux. The worst casting of the entire film. The worst acting. And the Nazi reference was just gag-inducing.The movie was ridden with non-sensical stuff. Star Wars used to make sense. There was a sensible lore. Force users needed intense training, or they stood zero chance. How about some scavenger - unrealised force powers or not - able to fly a totally unknown ship with such efficacy and impossible skill? She resisted powerful force mind probes. She could out force-grab a light saber. Rey was all but victorious over a trained and 'powerful' Sith apprentice? Flinn - a SPACE JANITOR and rookie Storm Trooper - virtually holds his own against this trained Sith with a Jedi weapon he's never used before? Seriously?And the incongruencies abound. Ren can deflect point blank blaster shots behind his back, but can't detect and defend himself from a distant shot from a wookie who screams and reveals his position? We're supposed to be impressed or scared of this guy? He displays awesome initial powers, but ends up almost totally inept, and little more than a tantrum-throwing teenager?Han solo, one of the baddest and coolest good characters gets murdered over a touchy-feeling family moment and thrown into an abyss? What a fitting end. (rollseyes)There are so many negative things to say about this movie. And the only positives are a few moments of wonderful cinematography and VFX. Even the score was sub-par, which is a shocker from the greatest of all time. Almost everything about TFA was abysmal. Some of the tone was there. But this was light years from the Star Wars we knew and loved thirty-plus years ago.No wonder. No mystery. No lore. No build up. NO SIGNIFICANT, BELIEVABLE OR INTERESTING DRAMA. A complete failure to set up the most basic emotive themes like the first movies explored so successfully.By the time I was halfway through the movie, I was repeatedly throwing my hands in the air. This is a horrid re-entry for a franchise that was supposed to be resurrected and freed from the incapable clutches of a next-to-incompetent George Lucas.Well, we found out there are more incapable movie makers and IP owners. 4 billion dollars bought what we knew and loved, and the most bland product was funneled through the bowels of idiocy and incompetence. Yet it appears they are going to end up recouping it all and actually profiting. Such is the current state of modern cinema.Shameful.30 years we waited for this. I had so much hope this would be good with no Lucas. It would have been so hard for it to fall further from my expectations. I am absolutely gob smacked it's being received so well.Has the bar been set this low?

Terrible movie. I got no idea what are the good comments are about.If so please advice me on this.1. The Republic Planets got DESTROYED by a bigger more powerful weapon. And what were their reactions? Absolutely nothing. They didn't even know the Resistance were there helping to Stop them being shoot AGAIN! 2. What with this bad father hood crap? Darth Vader and Luke, Han Solo and his Son. And probably this new girl is Luke daughter. They all are not great father which causes all these things! A new scheme already please.3. Luke won the war, destroyed the empire best weapon and their Sith lord how come The resistance and the Republic are so damn weak this past 30 years?The dark side created a better weapon. And the good side still fight with junks? Didn't even have any bombs on their plane machines to destroy the weapon... All thanks to Han Solo self carries bombs!4. And what with this so easy stuff? From fairy tail for adults is fairy tail for teenagers, nice visual effects, weak story
Horrible clone of the first movie.

Overhyped movie of this year. Basically a regurgitation of the first series of Star Wars. Complete with the heroine being just like her dad Luke living in the desert wanting nothing to do with the force. The Republic planets get destroyed again. Of course someone dies off the platform of the ship after their family member kills them. They have a new robot that has all the important info. Also they shoot to kill the death star again and the falcon js the ship of use. They have the scene of going into the weird creature bar all over again. Lots of cameos from the old crew still acting the same like hans solo owing ppl money. Action-packed, good acting, some humor, nice effects, but nothing new. The only surprise was that a girl was the heroine and that a storm trooper turned good. Yawn they played it too safe to the original franchise. I sincerely hope they up their game for the next one.

This movie was basically a complete rip-off of the original Star Wars movies.1. Android carrying message of extreme importance is sought after.2. Rey is a ripoff of Luke in every way, they are both orphans they both live on a desert world, and both are super powerful with the force yet do not realize it. 3. Death Star is "Big Weapon" in this movie4. Admiral and Kylo Ren have the same relationship as the Admiral and Darth Vader. Both at odds with methodology of crushing the resistance. 5. A cast of characters convenes and determines that the "Big weapon" has ONE tiny exploitable weakness.6. Darth Vader and Kylo Ren looks pretty much identical. 7. The father/son bond between the arch-villain and hero.8. The emperor is only presented as a mysterious figure via hologram. Need I go on? (spoilers) A disappointing number of questionable scenes top off by the scene where a newbie force user defeats a trained force user in her first light saber duel. The better scenes were the death of Hans Solo and parts of the new bar scene. Notable characters were General Hux and SL Snoke. There are some interesting mysteries for the next episode. Who will carry the movie after the death of Hans Solo? Has Luke been training Jedi in his hideout? Is SL Snoke really Darth Plagus?The saddest part of the movie was the plot. Couldn't they think of something besides the good guys saving the rebellion at the last minute by blowing up a planet/solar system killing machine?Speaking of which, didn't any science advisor point out that when you start draining a sun in a solar system you immediately allow all the planets to fly out of their orbits killing the populations within hours if not minutes?These defects turn this sci-fi fantasy into a sci-fi farce.
In an epic that takes place far, far away, it was far, far away from epic.
A shameless rip-off of EP4.
A riskless movie by and for FANS.
Bad story telling. Rushed. Wrong actors for the main characters (other than the usual).

Whilst changes to the saga were always going to happen, Star Wars feels like it's been shrunk down to planetary skirmishes.Although some plot items have been increased in size, the sense of scale that battles previously had has been lost, which is disappointing.When coupled to the hit and miss with the new characters, this feels like a film lacking the charm of either IV, V and VI or the updated wow factor which I, II and III had.

A big steaming pile of derivative garbage. This film does not stand on it's own two feet, relying heavily on nostalgia to prop up this un-original and labored plot. Screenwriter was the easiest job on this project by far, basically just changing the names on the storyline from the original (Episode IV). This was a pointless exercise in re-hashing, and its a shame the fanboys and fangirls seem to be giving it a free pass.

Just saw the movie last night for the first time. I opted for the 3D version, and took the family. First, the good. Visuals and quality of the scenes was excellent, and Disney (and Abrams) experience at making films and worlds that are easy on the eye was apparent. Abrams also did a nice job with lighting and angles on most of the shots which accentuated the characters and definition of each scene. The 3D was mostly spectacular, with not too much and not too little, but just the right amount of depth (with a few in your face "coolness" moments) to make the extra $ worth it. Resolution and clarity was excellent, although with all 3D movies due to the technology, brightness of the scenes continues to suffer somewhat.However, beyond the big budget quality of the film, there was not much more to like. The story line was dull, there was little suspense, portions of the acting seemed amateurish (Fin in particular), and I felt like I was watching a copy of the original movies. There were at least 3 moments in the film where I was visibly shaking my head back and forth and rolling my eyes over the predictable and downright plagiarist nature of the film (I won't spoil it).If you are expecting a seat of your pants, action thriller with new creative elements, and storylines that make you care about the characters, this movie is not for you. If you want to be mildly entertained for a few hrs by good 3D and pretty scenes, you won't be disappointed.

A good action film but not a great Star Wars film. Enjoyable to watch but the idea that Kylo Ren could be defeated by either Rey or or Finn is ridiculous, and that Chewbacca could have shot him is also ludicrous. Kylo is the least intimidating evil-doer and only managed to kill his father in a cowardly Vader-killing-Kenobi style scene. The final scene with Luke Skywalker made me crack up...

While the mass hysteria, expectations born 40 years ago and uber-hype surrounding Episode 7 may brainwash the millions of lemmings out there (and I realize I now risk incurring their wrath), the Force does not awaken, but rather slumbers through what is essentially a bloated remake of the beloved 1977 classic. A very good film for the new Star Wars generation without question, but for us old-school aficionados to which the original trilogy is cinematic scripture, it fails to deliver any lasting emotion, excitement or resonance. Another resistance, another Empire (now called The First Order), another Cantina, even a planet revamped and masquerading as a pseudo Death Star??? Seriously!?!?! I'm not being overly critical, really I'm not. I'm just being true to Lucas' original vision and trilogy and I know there must be other intelligent, genuine cinephiles out there in their 40s who agree with me and know exactly what I'm talking about. Make no mistake, this is not a terrible film. It's passable in every regard. But for those of us who remember the magic and majesty of the original trilogy, it's like having a sip of Coke from an open can that's been sitting on a counter for a month and has long lost its fizzle and taste.

Very disappointed. Same plot as original...blow up "death star" in basically the same way, same fighter battles, same light saber battles. Undeveloped relationship among protagonists, who fall for each other after one fight.
Not exactly a sequel, The Force Awakens is more like a re-telling of a familiar story.

Great effects, sound, acting and have it fills of funny moments, too bad the story feels too much like the original movie from 1977. I understand that they went for the old time feel of the classic but the story seems more of a copy then a continuation of the franchise. I hope it will open up for the next 5 movies to be more innovative and creative.

My O my. OK the rebel forces might be destroyed by a large weapon unless can shut down defenses to allow an attack to destroy it. Is this the first one or the third one or the 4th one...and the Jedis who can move stuff and kick ass....and can see the future sometimes....well..didn't/don't. I liked the movie for the same reason as most. I find it ironic that during the film the part that got the most cheers was the Millennium Falcon. Predictable Fun. JJ was true and loyal to the first three. I liked it and will probably see it again as it dribbles into the history of the universe. Was it bad...no....but if not a Star Wars Movie....the truth is I think most would say "it was Okay."
What a shitload of crap.
Like a band you loved reunion tour of greatest hits, but only two members are still alive and its directed by JJ Abrams.
It was a good nostalgic passing of the torch but I was hoping for a lot more innovation and creativity. It leaves some hope for 8 and 9 though.
More like a remake than a continuation, lacks originality.

Good job, JJ. Watchable (if a little bit too long) and a good mixture of the old and the new. Fun for the old fans, comprehensible to those of us who are less experts and more just along for the ride. But the highest praise of all for an excellent female lead role!

Its watchable but not as good as a Lucas film. The good bits: as a little walk down memory lane reminiscing of the old magic, the old crew (specifically Harrison Ford), Daisy Ridley, a lot of action. Daisy Ridley does one of the best jobs I've ever seen of portraying a powerful yet still feminine and human female role model.The bad bits: there's no heart or magic to this film (as there was in every Lucas film). Its just a rehash of old stuff with little character development or pause for atmosphere (something Lucas was great at). He made you feel. Feel part of the story. This is just a series of excitements occurring one after another. If Solo and Chewbacca were not in it, this would be nothing more than a so-so TV B-movie. Maybe this is what American teenagers want to pay to see. If thats the case, they're in for an exciting future because there's a promise of endless of these without Harrison Ford in them. A notable point of failure in the nostalgia - the Millennium Falcon, even having sat in a scrap yard and left rotting for decages, in this film worked better than it ever had.

After seeing it twice, I don't like it.First, the movie is a medley of sorts of the original trilogy (particularly ep. IV), only the plot is way more confusing. I keep reading additional content (like that Aftermath) and I still can't fully grasp what's the situation of the galaxy. It's a mess, and this should have been explained in the movie (having to dig information elsewhere is frustrating). Also, a new Death Star? Really?Second, the pacing is weird. The first half of the movie is somewhat stronger than the second. The ending feels like it doesn't fit and it doesn't feel much like Star Wars.Third, the villains are weak. You can't stop comparing Gen. "Mux" with Tarkin, "KillO'Ben" with Vader, and "Supreme Leader Snarf" with Palpatine - and they all fail to deliver (and it's not the actor's fault...). That Kylo Ren is the stupidest character since Jar Jar Binks. Nothing he says makes sense. "I'll finish what you started..." What did Vader start to begin with? Palpatine founded the Empire, Palpatine started hunting down the jedi, Palpatine started every war in both the classical and prequel trilogies... so what the heck is this kid talking about? Finally, having a loving father and mother, being son of two of the greatest heroes of the galaxy wasn't enough... Having the strongest force user as uncle and master is not enough... Somehow he bounded to Supreme Leader Snarf will and - then they repeat the plot again? At least we had 3 movies to try to understand Anakin's fall. By the way, nobody told this stupid kid that the grandfather he worships so much came back to the light before he died? Oh, but that's not enough. The stupid kid had to lose the lightsaber fight so we could grasp how dumb and weak he is. Kylo Ren is like "Cartman with Authoritah fell to the dark side" - but dumber.Forth, why wasn't the big imperial ships protecting the big bad base as well? Why that stupid name, "First Order"? Why captain Phasma lowered the shield (the price for such treason should be surely death or worse... oh, forget it). Why make lots of puppets and then make Maz Kanata CGI? The movie kept reminding me it was just a movie!Also, that dialogue between Han and Leia. So much of it was unnecessary... Which brings me to what I hated the most about the movie, and the main reason I'm giving it such a low score: it erases anything good and fulfilling we had at the end of Return of the Jedi. Every single one of the original heroes failed miserably in every aspects of their lives. Where is the reward for being good, just and do heroic deeds?So... Han failed as a husband, as a father, as a member of the resistance and overall as a man (a bitter one it seems)... same goes for Leia (oh, she is a general of a sidekick cell that's supported by the republic... great). Luke is the worse of them all: failed as a jedi master, failed as a protector of the galaxy, as uncle, as friend, as brother, as the owner of R2D2... the plot seemed to be around finding Luke, but the movie ends and he's done nothing and you get to wonder: why? Why do they need him? What do they need him for? The resistance certainly can handle any new Death Star that appears, and it seems the plumber trooper and junkyard girl can surely handle the stupid angry kid. All that, and R2D2 being in a coma because he's sad sounds so absurd... Didn't the little droid survived the killing of younglings by Anakin Skywalker? Didn't he watch the purge of the jedi and the founding of the Empire?Well, I guess that's it. I had to watch it 2 times to be sure I didn't like it, but the more I think about it, the worse it gets. I was going to keep it to myself, but after seeing how angry "the real fans" are getting at anyone that disagree with them, I felt I had to come and share with you, that also didn't like the movie, that you are not alone. I can only hope the next one will end up being so good it's going to redeem this one.
Boring, predictable, forced dialog, ridiculous casting (Carrie Fisher as Harrison Ford�s matronly and maudlin love interest who is also a General??! Pleeeease.
Didn't live up to the hype....
Ugh, let's be done with this Star Wars garbage, selling us pajamas etc.
kinda boring, nothing special. I don't see what all the fuss is about.
played out boring photo copy of previous Star Wars movies. Is suited for preteen audience. It was a waste of money....
like warmed up leftovers dry and tasteless.

Seen it and was disappointed, having seen all the old ones and purchased the games in the noughties I saw repeats of scenes and and no wow factor. Having seen the new Star Trek films, which by comparison were excellent this had no real storyline and did not seem to be advanced in years with new models of fighters or costumes (remember the old SMGs the star troopers had). Very disappointing for those that have been here before.

1. Snoke looks underdeveloped.2. Kylo Ren is played by an ugly repulsive person.3. Kylo Ren's lightsaber skills are disgustingly inferior to a person who never even held a lightsaber before.4. No Imperial March5. Phasma was promoted and hyped in so many ways and had three lines of speech in the entire movie.6. One additional star for BB-8 because it's awesome.7. It's got some nice J.J. Abrams Star Trek tricks but they are overabused this time around; and it's too nostalgic.

Prob not a spoiler by now? Can't deny the cultural hysteria that accompanied this event... it was definitely fun, even thrilling at moments, but in the end, it felt too much like its original predecessor and not enough creative originality in its own right to be deemed a classic or amongst the year's best.

WTF, that's some movie which i hated. I'm one of the first generation star wars fan's. but this movie is terrible. Self the bad boy is no secret anymore. When he is angry he destroys the Console with his lightsaber instead of killing the messanger. There is not really any story behind it. just a combination of old topics. Nothing is really new. And the new Actors are terrible. This movie don't deserve a rating at all. That's more made for from the production straight into the video store. terrible

Re: Star Wars: The Force Awakens --I have been a Star Wars fan since I went to the theater to see the first movie (Ep.4). I've read most of the books that follow Ep.6. .I had heard that Disney did not want George Lucas involved (somewhat understandable after Ep.1), but they have obviously decided that they also could care less about long-time Star Wars fans & the existing Star Wars storyline. The one thing that Lucas did right is that he insured that the books, TV series, etc. were all consistent re: the long-term storyline. Disney obviously decided that this was no longer necessary & COMPLETELY changed what occurs in the future of the original characters. For example: in the books, Leia & Han have a really good marriage & have 3 children: twins Jacen & Jaina & younger son Anakin. Luke does not disappear, but instead marries & has a son Ben. Various things happen to all of them, but nothing like this movie. Han doesn't die in the books. The children & the names of the kids have been changed. (Han's son "Ben" does not even remotely look like he could be the son of Han & Leia btw.) The 3 main characters have dire things happen to them, but nothing like this movie. I own all of the previous dvd's. I own almost every Star Wars book made .(I read many books, but especially science fiction.) I HATED this movie. I will not buy this dvd, nor will I go to the movies to see the next 2 episodes or buy those dvd's. I'm not sure if I will ever go to a theater to see another Disney movie after what they've done with this movie. I resent the fact that they felt that long-term fans are irrelevant & could be disregarded in this way. Disney (& JJ Abrams) really screwed up the Star Wars franchise (IMO obviously) far worse than George Lucas ever did.PS- 2 dimensional characters & minimal plot didn't help the movie either.

Good Remake. Well executed, not very good BUT... the end lacks a little script. Not sure if it was planned to have a REALLY bad last 5min.

I have seen all Star Wars movies and unfortunately including this one.When J.J Abrams did a reboot of Star Trek, I was pleasantly surprised even as I was dismayed that Star Trek was turned into something it was not--a low brow action flick. But I also enjoyed the sequel--Star Trek: Into Darkness--with some reservation.Back to Star Wars: I did not like this movie and I did not understand what it's intent was. The story telling was poor, the acting was poor, the animation was poor , the use of 3D was poor and it did not have the largess of a typical Star Wars movie. It lacked polish through and through and it turned the force into a side joke. It might be fair to say that it destroyed Star Wars for any loyal fan. I am not sure of the impact it will have for younger viewers who have never seen Star Wars before this one.My expectations might have been too high, but the only person who has done Star Wars right so far has been George Lucas.I can suspect that the challenge of rebooting a franchise can be a daunting task. I am sure that the was work was hard and it is easy to be a critic, but this was a poorly done movie.

The ideas in this screenplay must have come from a fear of failure rather than an opportunity to create a new fresh path that would add to the Star Wars franchise. They take the "Luke I am your Father" idea from "Empire" and transfer it to Harrison Ford this time. Then they take the Death Star idea and from the original Star Wars and just give it the ability to kill multiple planets at the same time. And the protagonists are not real. The Daisy Ridley character is an expert at everything! In the original Star Wars we hear that Luke is an excellent pilot but he must spend time training with Obi Wan to gain skills with the light sabre -- then when he fights its believable! Not Rey -- she's an expert pilot, mechanic, and an instantaneous expert at with the light sabre with no training at all -- she defeats the main antagonist who has ostensibly spent his life training with the light sabre for the dark side. When we go into a film like this we know of course it's not real -- and so its the job of the writers to draw us in by making the characters feel real human which means they all have certain strengths and weaknesses -- They really need to let George write theses stories as he's a very creative writer -- this is his baby and he knows where it needs to go.

This review is rated SPOILERIFIC by Fly Casual Podcast. Virgin eyes and ears have been warned.The Force Awakens is here! FINALLY! After a year and a half of all the news, rumors and outright wackiness (at least from the crew at Fly Casual Podcast), we have our first taste of the new age of Star Wars. JJ Abrams and Disney deliver on the most anticipated movie of the year in a BIG way. As I write, The Force Awakens has been crowned king of the domestic box office $770 Million in gross receipts and has broken a myriad of records. Worldwide, the film is currently at $1.5 Billion with the movie opening in China today. The movie is at 93% Fresh on Rotten Tomatoes. What's not to like about this movie?There are a million different angles you can take on this, so instead of me trying to rationalize each and show how smart I think I am for having such a broad view, I am just going to give you my background with Star Wars to set the stage for this review so you get the sense of where I am coming from. I am a forty-something who has seen all of the films in the theater, albeit A New Hope was at the 1979 re-release. I grew up in the 80's with my Kenner Star Wars toys and have been there since the beginning. I avidly partook in what was called the Star Wars Expanded Universe (EU) which is all the books, games, and extra-movie material that came out almost from day one. I am what you would call an uber-fan of Star Wars. Not only is The Empire Strikes Back my favorite of the movies, I think it is one of the greatest films of all time. I love John Williams's scores for the films. I love Ben Burt's sound production. When people think of how a laser bolt sounds, they are actually hearing Ben Burt hitting a ground wire on a telephone pole with a wrench and the resulting vibrations. I am deeply entrenched in this stuff to the point that I co-host a Star Wars podcast with other Uber nerds and debate this stuff. I appreciate George Lucas's vision, but I am not an apologist. The man has flaws and they were on full display in the prequels. But don't get me wrong; I don't hate the prequels. Like most people leading up to this movie I had fun debating what we would see with the Disney/JJ Abrams incarnation. Listeners of Fly Casual over the last year and a half know how deeply we delved into these discussions. It's been lots and lots of fun. BUT, would the movie live up to the hype?As regular listeners of the show know, I was "not available" on December 17 when the rest of the Fly Casual crew went to see the movie and recorded Episode 70 live immediately after the movie. Following is my addendum to that episode.I have now seen the movie 4 times. Believe it or not, I saw it 3 times in the first 24 hours! I didn't realize this until a friend pointed it out. The first was by myself the evening of the 17th. I couldn't see it with the guys, but made it happen later at the 11:15 showing at our local theater. This was by far, my least favorite of the four times due in part to my criticisms of the film, a bladder FULL of Diet Coke, and over 3 hours of run time when you include trailers! My second viewing was the next day with my business partner. We skipped out and saw the film at the same theater at the 11 AM showing. My criticisms remained, but my "under-control-bladder" situation helped immensely with increased enjoyment levels. Later the same evening, my kids begged me to take them, so what's a dad to do? I felt pretty much the same at this viewing that I did at the viewing earlier in the day, but we were in a different theater that had the volumes MUCH higher and at a far more enjoyable level for me.My final viewing was in IMAX 3D. Now, our local "IMAX" theaters aren't true 70mm, but I am not a fan of 3D to begin with and this viewing did little to change that. I am not sure that seeing the film in 70mm would have helped, BUT the sound was even better with the demonstrably superior sound system in the theater.So let's just get this out there now. I am not "gaga" over the film as most people are and the way that most of my cohorts on Fly Casual are. I don't dislike the film. It was good! It has some very strong points. But the movie is not the home run I had hoped for leading up to its release. So let's get into the nitty gritty.The GoodGoing into the film, EVERYONE was buzzing about the "practical effects" that JJ Abrams planned to employ in the film. For the most part, he did not disappoint. Many felt like one of the things that made the original trilogy great was Lucas's limitations with special effects that forced him to rely on landscapes and well-conceived camera angles to deliver his film. When the effects-heavy prequels rolled around, Lucas seemingly forgot what made the originals great and embraced what many feel were lifeless performances by his actors due to lack of directing and nothing but green-screen sets to play off while delivering their performances. Abrams seems to have found the right balance of special effects and live sets. The film certainly felt more grounded, even if some of the sets and landscapes were too reminiscent of past films. If it looks like Tatooine and sounds like Tatooine and smells like Tatooine then why are we on Jakku???? In my opinion, Daisy Ridley stole the show. The character Rey was the right amount of everything: vulnerable, strong, gorgeous, expressive, funny, and "Roberta Badass." Some are actually criticizing the character as being a "Mary Sue," but I am all about it. She is definitely the new Luke in the series and I am excited about having an intriguing female character like this being the new lead in Star Wars.Lupita Nyong'o's character, Maz Kanata, almost, stole the show from Rey... almost. By far she had my favorite line in the movie, "Where's my boyfriend? I love that Wookie." The character is a Yoda analogue; a character that has been around for a millennia and has seen it all. With lines like, "I have lived long enough to see the same eyes in different people. I see your eyes. I know your eyes" one would think that in order to portray such a deep character you would need a wizened sage of an actor. Well look no further than barely-30-something Nyong'o. Her performance was brilliant. Han Solo is one of those iconic characters you don't want to screw up. Everyone is thankful for Harrison Ford and his $23 million return to the role. Han and Chewie are definitely a highlight of the film. There were a few times that Ford showed his age (running away from rathtars) and one time that Abrams skated dangerously close to the absurd (no-look shooting). But he represented the old guard well going toe to toe with Ridley and Boyega. He brilliantly portrayed a still brash and reckless Han Solo who IS 30 years older AND wiser. He will be missed from the franchise. I don't want to say that John Boyega's character Finn was the "surprise" hit of the film, but it felt that way to me. By all accounts leading up to the film, he was a talented actor and was expected to be the next Luke Skywalker in the series. I shouldn't have been surprised, but I was because going in, our only real exposure to him was one or two lines in the trailers and a lot of desert sweating. A LOT of sweating. To my delight, I loved Finn's character, who, by the way, is closer to a Han Solo than a Luke Skywalker. Finn is a loner who wants to run away as far as he can from the First Order. He does this to the point that he is lying to EVERYONE around him about his true intentions. If not for his affinity for Rey, he would have been long gone, much like Han's affinity for Leia in the original trilogy and desire to have nothing to do with the Rebellion. He was certainly a heavy part of the comic relief. I am interested to see where this character goes. I think I know where just about everyone else is going. Finn is up in the air.Adam Driver's character Kylo Ren has received mixed reviews from the people with whom I have spoken. Most critics are saying that he is not "evil" enough to be the new trilogy's villain. He is whiny and out of control. To me, these are the things I LOVE about him. Here is a darkside Force user who is being tempted by the LIGHT! He is a Skywalker! I am actually glad that we have a villain that isn't a scarred-beyond-recognition-amputee! I want to know more about him. Why did he betray Luke and the Jedi? What happened during the rebellion? Why is he so obsessed with Vader? How does Snoke play into his betrayal. I also thought that despite having to set up this character very fast to get to the payoff of the Solo death scene, both he and Ford played it as well as it could be played. From the tear shedding by Ren that had us believing for a moment that he was going to go with his father to the final touch of Solo's hand on Ren's face. Kudos on the performance. I am a fan. The BadAnyone who knows me understands that Luke was my hero growing up. The day I heard we were getting Ep VII and that the original cast was back I started conjuring images in my mind of Luke's return to the silver screen and the badassery that must ensue. Fast forward to December 18. Saying I was a little disappointed would be an understatement. I get it. The movie turned into the quest for Luke. Rumors early on were suggesting a very limited role for Mark Hamill in the film. I was somewhat prepared, but I really didn't think we wouldn't even be getting a single line from Luke. Listeners of Fly Casual know about what we call the "Fan Boy Wet Dream." In said "dream" scenario our hope was more along the lines of Luke being found and participating in the final battle sequences. Instead we get a robed figure turning around and pulling down his hood. Que music. I am taking this as well as I can and hoping for previously mentioned badassery to commence in VIII AND IX. Don't let me down Rian!John Williams is THE MAN! He has written every major movie score throughout my youth, formative years, and adulthood. The man is a genius with scores like Star Wars, ET, Indiana Jones, Jaws, Harry Potter, and a million others. The man is also 83 years old. The score for this film felt like an 83 year old man wrote it. What I mean is that it is not very memorable, with the exception of classic trilogy themes, I really don't remember the soundtrack at all. Even though Attack of the Clones is my least favorite of the films, I still remember the Anakin/Padme love theme which was brilliant. The best I can say about the new score is that I remember hearing the Rey theme and remember liking it, but please don't ask me to hum it. This is more than a little disappointing. Part of the problem is that the sound track in general is mixed poorly in my opinion (see The Ugly below). It feels like JJ called up Williams, and in his head was like, "What?! Another one?" They paid him a bajillion dollars and he futzed his way through it. I will be frankly surprised if he returns for VIII at 85 years old. I think they should have thought more long term, ripped off the Band-Aid, and made the change now.I remember our very first cast of Fly Casual in the summer of 2014 and talking about Disney choosing JJ Abrams to direct. We saw JJ's involvement as a double edged sword. We all knew what he could do with "look and feel" through "Super 8" and the Star Trek reboots. But one of our earliest criticisms of him was that he tended to sacrifice story and originality for said "look and feel." The more the rumors and images poured in over the next year and a half. The more concerned we became. Unfortunately he did not prove us wrong. In many many ways, this film is almost a complete replica of A New Hope complete with desert dwellers, a young idealistic kid, a sage old man, a rogue, droid carrying secret data, a masked villain, and on and on and on. After seeing The Force Awakens, I am happy that JJ was involved, but I am somewhat relieved he won't be back for snow planets, metal walking tanks, and a city in the clouds called "Jackee" in Ep VIII. Can anyone explain who or what is the Republic? I thought there should be more exposition there. Now I do realize that the "Empire" was pretty vague at the time of A New Hope, but I think that was out of necessity at that time. I think they could have been clearer about the status of Coruscant and the New Republic. Captain Phasma: wait, what? Rathtars: Unnecessary. Didn't feel like Star Wars.The UglyAlluded to above, my biggest complaint with this film, by FAR, is the sound track. By "soundtrack," I don't mean the just the music. The music was only the tip of the ice berg. I mean the sound effects, the music, and the mix. Why they felt like they had to completely recreate the sound of laser bolts is beyond my comprehension. When they purchased Lucasfilm, they inherited Ben Burt's sound library complete with the most recognizable laser sound effects in existence. When someone describes a laser blast, I would argue that most people hear Ben Burt's version. Suddenly laser rifles sound like crappy 1970's sci-fi. I was stunned. Even light sabers were changed. HOW ON EARTH DO YOU SCREW UP LIGHT SABERS?! I'll even give them a pass on Kylo Ren's lightsaber since it is "unique." But Skywalker's light saber sounded more like a jet engine! Part of the reason none of the music was memorable to me is that I couldn't hear it most of the time. Foreign Correspondent Steve Potter in the UK shares many of my criticisms of the film. He has told me that he has purchased the musical score and after listening to it, isolated from the film, he actually likes it. If that is the case, if there really is good music to present, why the hell is it tucked so deep into the sound track? After my first viewing of the film, I was downright mad. Now part of that was because of previously said full bladder. But even after my second and third viewing, that criticism remained. I will admit that at my 4th viewing at the IMAX Theater, I was able to hear many of the classic and familiar sounds I missed in previous viewings, BUT I still had to concentrate to hear them. I felt like the soundtrack was REALLY rushed on this film... almost to the point that the film was unrecognizable and unenjoyable to me. Call me an uber-nerd if you want and you're probably right that most people don't care or recognize this as a problem, but I do. With JJ Abrams reputation for look and feel, this was an unexpected misstep in my opinion. As previously discussed, JJ's "return to the well" of A New Hope was a noticeable problem. The icing on the cake is Deathstar 3, aka Starkiller Base. This was an absolute eye roller to me. There HAD to be another way to bring the film to a climatic end. That was just damn poor writing, Mr. Kasdan. When the Resistance was in the war room and Poe pulled up the side-by-side of the Deathstar and Starkiler base, I thought I was going to lose it. JJ is getting a LOT of flack right now from Lucas and other critics for making a "nostalgia film." Had there not been a Deathstar 3, I would stand in defense of him. He honestly deserves all the criticism he gets for that one. This is a total lack of creativity in my opinion.My final criticism of the film will only be relatable to fans of the EU. Many of us waited eagerly to see if beloved EU characters Jacen & Jaina (Han and Leia's twin children) would make their big screen debut in The Force Awakens in the form of Kylo Ren and Rey. We knew there was at best a 50/50 chance these characters would transition over to the New Canon (or Disney's newly established Star Wars timeline which renders most of the prior EU irrelevant). But not only did they tell us that Jacen and Jaina will not exist, but they also flipped us the bird when they revealed Kylo Ren's birth name to be "Ben" Solo. You see, in the old EU, Luke's son's name was Ben. I know some in my circle of friends are patiently waiting and hoping for revelations/explanations or even other EU characters to end up in the movies. In my mind this is a clear sign that the EU will have no place in the new movies, and frankly, this disappoints me. I will still enjoy the films. I enjoyed this film. But it would have been nice to feel like the filmmakers threw the uber-fans a bone. The LowdownStar Wars films evolve over time with me. Right now, I can't give this film more than 3 out of 5 stars. Good movie. I really enjoyed it. My kids enjoyed it. The film will become part of my collection. But it just doesn't have the classic feel with me yet. I am not certain about the staying power. I will say that I am glad that there is mystery returning to the saga. With the prequels, you always knew where they were headed. That is an inherent problem with prequels. With these new sequels, anything is possible again and THAT is exciting!My Star Wars order of favorite movies:1. The Empire Strikes Back2. A New Hope3. Return of the Jedi4. The Force Awakens5. Revenge of the Sith6. The Phantom Menace7. Attack of the Clones

I liked the movie. But it felt like episode of TV show rather than full feature, especially with all but "to be continued" after two hours of watching. I also had a feeling that I saw this movie before:Fool em' once - shame on the Sith Lord, fool twice twice - shame on rebels, fool them thrice - Star Wars: The Force Awakens!

Don't read if you haven't seen this movie. I was very disappointed to see that some of the cast members were recognizable stars from other shows/films. One of the best things about the series is the new faces. I don't want to see the stars from "Heroes" or "Girls" because it distracts from who they are meant to be in this film. Also, if you are going to cast the biological grown child of two characters, at least find someone who looks as though they MIGHT have come from them. Oh, and don't kill off the most popular character in the entire series! I won't be buying this movie.
Generally a decent movie, but if your looking for a film theory plot line, your going to be incredibly disappointed.

It's as good as the other Star Wars movies. The excuse for a plot in this one is the same as the excuse for a plot in the original. The one good thing about this movie is that it's gotten JJ Abrams away from the Star Trek films, so maybe they'll have a plot again.
Worst actress and actor ever! Story is pretty bullshit.

If you get past the hype... and get past the carbon copy of A New Hope... and If you can get passed the weak villains that don't evoke fear or a feeling of power... then you may like the greatest thing about this film. The creation of BB8. Save some money and re-watch A New Hope.

Good acting, horrible plot. The lack of originality is massive, the screewriters and Abrams should be ashamed of the amount of plagiarism they put here. Copycat planets, copycat characters, copicat story. The movie is not a bad one, but with all the resources they had the results are embarassing.

I wish I could give it less than half a star. Standalone, this movie would probably not be so bad. It would simply be another Disney movie. But it's not a standalone movie. and.. it was not supposed to be a Disney production.. (thank you Lucas.. hope you enjoy your millions). It's supposed to be a Star Wars sequel!After watching it opening night.. it was simply another disaster in a long line of disasters perpetrated by mega corporations on people's fond memories of films past. At least Jurassic World tried some to preserve the continuity of the original trilogy. Barring a few goofy missteps with raptors fighting alongside humans, it was a fairly entertaining remake. I had no hard feelings... but Star Wars is special.. It's our childhood. This movie made me appreciate the prequels! Have no desire to watch what happens next.. How can anyone want to see more? What's the "Empire Strikes Back" to this? The inept first order who only possessed one weapon requiring hours of charging and ignored buying some extra fleets of tie-fighters for good measure if they were swarmed? A goofy post-pubescent villain who evoked laughter rather than instill fear when he removed his mask. I was reminded of the time Dark Helmet in Space Balls removed his.. at least that movie was funny!How was the "force" the underdogs in this plot? Why go through the entire movie trying to find a lost Luke? Is he unreachable via the force? More importantly what's his role? We already have our Mary Sue to the rescue. She could very well have conjured a petronus charm and waved off all evil from the galaxy. I understand the need to provide a strong role model for 10 year old girls; movie seems to be targeted at the Frozen audience in that way..but seriously, even 10 year old girls know better and will hate this movie! Viewers are being misled. I am highly skeptical of the unusually large number of positive reviewers showered at this movie so close to release. It just rubs the cynical in me the wrong way. No way so many people liked it..anyone I run across who's watched it has mixed feelings or disliked it totally. But I guess studios have to create the hype for box-office ratings.I think this movie was riding on the success of the earlier movies. A true measure of success for this movie will be the second one.. which will have to stand on the shoulders of this disaster. Let's see how that goes. Will buy used dvd's for the next two to see what happens.. no way am I going to throw good money at this corporatized ideological nonsense. Maybe they hand it over to Michael Bay.. at least the action scenes would have some life.. cuz the rest of it is just one big black hole.
The absolute worst film of 2015! This is a paint by numbers retread of A New Hope. And it completely betrays the original characters, and everything it stands for!
Entertaining but dissapointing at the same time. Too many plot holes to look past. Some parts felt rushed.
take away FX and what do you have? nostalgia and an implausible, not to mention recycled, plot, utterly lame dialogue

I will never bad mouth the prequels again. Never made a connection with the characters, can't even remember their names. J.J. Abrahams doesn't have an original thought in his head, this is just a rehash of the originals movies.
Worst Star Wars Movie to date, thanks Jar Jar Abrams!
The first order and the republic are all fighting for who gets to meet this person, Luke Skywalker, first.I don't get this movie

I?m NOT a ?Star Wars? fan. Never have been, fortunately. But always loved watching action/science fiction movies. When I checked the internet, everywhere I saw that this movie had broken all Box Office records. Then I thought maybe, just maybe, this movie would be special . But it?s not, sadly.I found a lot of negatives than positives. Let me talk about the good part first. The special effects/graphics are amazing! And by ?special effects?, I also mean the beautiful landscapes on different planets, the action, the spaceships and the droids. (I loved BB8 in the movie). And now the negatives. The two things that I disliked the MOST are the story and the acting (by most of the actors).It?s difficult t prove my point without giving spoilers, but it is true that a LOT of the plot elements/ incidents are very similar/same to what has happened in the previous six movies. I was sincerely hoping that Lucas would take the story in brand new direction. But how wrong I was. Almost everything seemed like a repetition of what occurred in the earlier movies. I thought Lucas was very creative. But for some reasons, he decided not go for something original; he just presented the very same concept, that had worked many years back, again. Now about the acting. The veterans have done a great job. Ford (as Han Solo) was remarkable and Fisher (as Leia) was also nice but her role was quite less. Most of the newer/ younger cast were disappointing. John Boyega (as Finn) was irritating. Adam Driver (as Kylo Ren) failed to live up to his role. Ren is actually a very evil character but Driver just didn?t do much justice to the role. Daisy Ridley (as Rey) was very good but sadly her character itself was not sketched properly. What I mean is, Rey is actually a scavenger, surviving by herself on a hostile junkyard of a planet. Now such a person should be very tough and emotionless but she seemed to get emotionally attached to a lot of people. She seemed like a teenage fangirl when she says ?THE Han Solo!!?!!? and ?Luke Skywalker!!??!!!?. Overall, the film has failed to meet my expectations. I was expecting a lot from this film, in all the departments. The story was again a rehash of the previous movies. Most of the newcomer actors were not fit to play the roles they were assigned. After seeing this movie, it?s pretty easy to guess what?s going to happen in the sequel. I was never a ?Star Wars? fan and this movie has failed to change that.

Great special effects, dull and samey plot with way too many cringeworthy references to the previous films and I thought some of the acting was poor. I actually nodded off twice...l love Star Wars but I was disappointed with this one :(

The first sequel in the new Star Wars sequel trilogy has been hyped up all year. Its been used to basically advertise everything, from trucks, to batteries, to oranges, etc. The movie was directed by J.J Abrams, though he was only brought in to direct The Force Awakens and not the other two in the sequel trilogy. The story, setting, and characters feel rehashed to a really big extent, It has good characters for the most part,and It feels like its rushed.  To begin with it has a really unoriginal plot. It basically mirrors A New Hope and the ending of The Empire Strikes Back. Most of its characters feels like rehashes like Rey being a copy and paste of Luke Skywalker. The settings feel exactly the same but with different names. Jakku is basically Tatoonie, its houses look the same, and the desert looks the same, just with a bunch of destroyed Rebel and Empire vehicles everywhere. The First Order's Starkiller Base is literally just a giant Death Star with a different name. It feels lazy altogether and could of used more creativity.  The Characters in the movie are hit or miss. Rey is too boring and dry. Kylo Ren is a Darth Vader fanatic who is childish, impatient and whiny. He throws a big temper tantrum when something doesn't go his way, which makes me hate him as a villain. Which is a good job to me.The character Finn in the movie was actually pretty good as he brought a new point of view as a defecting First Order storm trooper. A over hyped character named Captain Phasma appears for like 3 scenes and barely does anything, a total disappointment . Some of the actors from the original Star Wars trilogy comes back and they put on a pretty good performance. Most of the acting isn't bad but the acting that is, is down right terrible. Finally, the film feels rushed and made to only sell because of name not story. It seems extremely stale in the beginning and becomes exciting towards the end with tons of action. If they took more time it would go beyond of being a sub par movie. I would recommend seeing it, its a good OK movie for today's standards but nothing special. The original trilogy was special because it was made to be something different and was different from its time. The Force Awakens feels like it was trying to be too much like the original trilogy, but failed because of it.

Shallow and undeveloped characters, Hollywood computer graphics that bore intelligent watchers, and unimportant but large societies that stage battles over what? What do either of the enemies have as societies that anyone cares about except that the good side wins against the evil side.
Disney's first 'Star Wars' adventure amounts to mere fan service whenit could have been a more meaningful extension of a beloved mythos.
Recycled, inconsistent & shallow.
Terrible, the worst Star Wars to date. It is just a rehash of the original. It could have been so much better

Semi spoiler review. Read at your own risk if you have not seen the movie and want to find out for yourself. Being an avid Star Wars fan I would have to say this movie was not anywhere up to par of where it should have been. Don't get me wrong it was a good movie but it could have been 100x better. The story is completely broken. Yes I know when star wars came out back in 1977 it was to also broken but at the same time George had the scripts made out to give the foundation for episodes 4, 5, and 6. I really commend Disney for bringing back Harrison Ford, Carrie Fisher, Mark Hamill and others that were part of the original saga but they screwed this up big time. I mean come on to me this looked like they took episodes 4 and 6 combined them together and added small pieces of the ending from episode 3 and called it a new movie. Come on if I wanted to see those movies again I would have just put them in my DVD player. The ending of episode 6 eliminates the Sith and the Imperial forces and in 7 all of a sudden you have a new Sith Lord with an apprentice. Where is the story at of where the Sith survived the destruction of the Death Star how they came to be. Then lets take the Death Star blow it up in size by 1000x (using a planet this time) and call it something completely different when in all actuality its still yet another Death Star. This is not original at all George Lucas did this twice. Terrible idea Disney. Then lets blow it up in almost the exact same way that it was blown up in Episode 6. While they are working on blowing it up lets take the way that episode 3 ends with Darth Vader getting his limbs chopped off left for dead and do almost the exact same thing to Kylo Ren except this time all we are going to do is put some cuts and slices on him from a lightsaber. Come on I have seen this already. Yes I know George Lucas was just a consultant on this movie but why have him as a consultant if every single idea that he gives you shoot down.I know I am probably being overly critical about this movie but I wanted to see something new something exciting and for me this movie did not do it all. Some of the graphics in my opinion were not George Lucas quality graphics. The lightsabers looked fake. To many edges and looked more like fire then a semi solide beam of light. And there are many more in the graphics that could have been much better.For this movie out of 5 stars I give a 2.5 and the only reason it gets this is because it did have some good action scenes. Even though the lightssabers looked fake to me the lightsaber battles were good. There was some suspense in the middle of the movie when the rebellion comes to help but after that the movie just falls off into the same old thing as before.I hope that when and if they release Episode 8 they do a much better job at telling the story and filling in the gaps that should have been put into this movie and make it 100x better in all aspects. The story, graphics, and even the battles.I wanted to see the Force Awakens not see hey heres the force it never left at all.
Great Movie, Shit Star Wars film. Really disappointing, and completely undermines the Original Trilogy.
Deja vu. I liked the George Lucas films better
It was good to see the old faces and the Star Wars universe, but the story is weak and too much like E4.
very disappointing. at best a rehash of the original and other episodes. Harrison ford was only bright spot and he is history in so many ways. don't waste your money - see it at home.

it was whack it didn't live up to the last six episodes.

Story: D+Light Side Casting: B+Dark Side Casting: DVisuals: ASound Effects: AMusic/Score: CTHERE WILL BE SIGNIFICANT SPOILERS IN THIS REVIEWI read the gushing reviews, I heard from friends how amazeballs this movie was, and I went in with hope, hope that this would not fall prey to the failures of the prequels. This movie was better than the prequels, but there are still significant failings (although there is good here too)VISUALSVisually this movie is stunning, similar to JJ Abrams work in the Star Trek reboots. However, image isn't everything unfortunately, and the visuals can't make up for other failings (specifically storyline related)MUSIC/SCOREWhen I hear certain songs from the original, they conjure up images of specific characters, locations or entire scenes. There was a magic to the music of the originals and there is not one song that stuck with me from this film that will bring me back to it when I hear it.LIGHT SIDE CASTINGI felt that both Finn, Rey and BB8 were fantastic additions to the series and show promise. Poe fell a bit flat for me as did the CGI lady in the poor man's Cantina scene with the big glasses.DARK SIDE CASTINGMan, where do I begin? Kylo Ren, initially, is pretty cool, when he keeps his mask on. When he stops Poe's blaster bolt in midair AND holds it there, pretty damned impressive (even Darth could only swat away a bolt, never saw him stop one).But it's when the mask comes off that the character just loses all appeal. His visage doesn't inspire terror, fear or respect. He struts around like a temper-tantrum throwing man-child.Likewise, the General for the New Order was horribly cast as well, failing to inspire any confidence in his abilities to lead this galaxy-dominating armada. He, too, comes across as a temper-tantrum throwing man-child who is constantly tossing snarky remarks at Kylo Ren.Further destroying some of the immersion is that Kylo Ren looks nothing like Han and Leia's son, not one ounce.COMEDYThe comedy in this film, for me, was fantastic. A lot of hilarious moments that elicited outright laughter from the audience. JJ Abrams did this with the Star Trek reboots as well and succeeded I feel.STORYLINE AND PAYING HOMAGE TO THE ORIGINALSWhere this film really falters is that it tries too hard to pay homage to the originals. It pays so much homage, that it outright copies them, to the detriment of this film.The problem is that Abrams went too far in paying homage, which prevents this film from having it's own stand-out moments, its own ability to shine on its own merits.There is yet another super weapon, conveniently with a glaring weakness to exploit, this time it's just all bigger (the super weapon AND the weakness). And while the super weapon draining a sun to power itself was cool to see, the battle to stop it was a huge let-down. Sure, you get X-Wings and Tie Fighters, but that's it. Where are the massive capital ships, frigates and fleets to slug it out? We get none of that and this battle fails to pack any punch.Another major issue is the development of the two primary characters, Finn and Rey. Finn is just thrust upon us with little introduction, little reason to care about him or to even understand his decision to flee the New Order. We discover he was assigned to sanitation duty, yet we also see him participating in a ground assault and later he is able to outgun experienced tie fighter pilots in a ship he's unfamiliar with, doing a task (gunner) that one can only assume he is equally unfamiliar with. Later he almost holds his own in a lightsaber duel with an experienced Sith.Rey is too good. She's an orphaned scavenger who can fix things, fly things, shoot guns with perfect accuracy, duel with lightsabers and develops her force powers in about one minutes time and is then able to challenge a trained and experienced Sith in combat. Remember all the training that Luke had and he still struggled? Yeah, well we don't really get that here.Some would argue "oh, she's just a natural!" but I say poppycock! She's a natural at fixing things, shooting blasters, flying, lightsabers and the force? C'mon son!BB8 is a welcome addition to the franchise and has his own comedic moments and is certainly no Jar Jar.Han's death was painfully obvious and quite clich� in how it went down. Leia struggles to stand out like she did in the originals, Carry Fisher has been away from acting for too long methinks.Overall this film was a giant disappointment for me. Although there is some hope, perhaps a New Hope, on the horizon. With the director behind Looper at the helm of the next film, perhaps there is something that can be salvaged. I definitely feel that the new light side cast can help this trilogy shine, hopefully the dark side cast doesn't drag it down too much.
One of the worst movies I have seen in a long time. Fell asleep. Loved all of the other ones...

In trying to recapture what made 'Star Wars' so special, director J.J. Abrams and new franchise owner Disney decided to introduce a bevy of young characters, along with some old fan favorites, over a plot that is -- for all intents and purposes -- the same as George Lucas' original film. Star Wars has always been mythic storytelling, and even the prequels featured elements mirroring the original films. But this entire approach struck me as lazy and trying to play it over-safe. To make matters worse, Abrams kind of already did this with his rebooted take on 'Star Trek' -- I expected more of him, frankly. To the filmmakers' credit however, the new cast shows a lot of promise; under the guidance of a director less willing to hang themselves up on nostalgia and take some chances, this could bode well for further installments of the new trilogy.
Just the same old formulaic b.s. I wish I didn't get sucked in and had my money back.

Same rehash of original movie: fater against son, the bad guys have a super weapon which has to be destroyed. Rey is the female version of Luke many years later. Very little originality in this movie. I had much higher expectations especailly after all the promotions andso many postive reviews. Major disappointment!

Jar Jar Abrams blowed it up, blowed it up real good!!! Wow, what a piece of crap!!Worst. Star Wars. Ever. Whoever had a hand in this movie should hang their head in shame. I wish that I could un-see it.

An admission to start - I was never a Star Wars fan.But after seeing this latest mess I am utterly convinced that to think it is great cinema you simply need to have been touched by 'the force'........An illogical plot, bordering on the inane; simply awful acting - with even stars with a reasonable reputation, such as Harrison Ford, embarrassing themselves (though, perhaps death by light sabre is supposed to elicit a C grade death), and derivative in almost every way a movie can be.This is dross. Awful movie. No new ideas were introduced in this film at all. The Force Awakens makes episodes one through 3 look like masterpieces. The characters are bland and have basically no depth. Mind you, I've watched this movie twice, and i found it even more enraging the second time through.

Really unimpressed with this film. It just is a recycled version of the first star wars film released in 1977. But much worse than that film. The characters are wooden. I did not buy the relationship between rey and finn nor the rey's ability to channel the force so immediately. Or the relationship between Han solo and Leia. Why not take more risk and make an interesting sequel to the other films? There is no way a film like this can lose money and yet they went the safe way.

For me this movie was incredibly painful. There were constant flaws within the character's stories and within the overall plot itself. Everything felt forced and rushed along as JJ Abrams tired his best to smash in all the Easter eggs he could that would give old timers a sense of nostalgia and make them forget what a bad movie they're watching.My problem with (inappropriate) humor:  Don't get me wrong, I've enjoyed humor in the previous films of Star Wars but this movie felt like a Marvel superhero film, with humor added in all the wrong situations. Star Wars films (the good movies) have a history of having darker tones until, despite all odds, the heroes barely manage to escape, where Marvel movies have gotten a reputation for lighthearted, funny movies without any real danger posing significant threat. Jokes are inserted at inappropriate times, ruining the gravity of grave situations for the heroes in The Force Awakens. The biggest example of this is when star-pilot Poe Dameron is captured and when face-to-face with the newly introduced Kylo Ren blabs out "So who talks first?" and other light hearted dialogue to get some cheap laughs out of the audience. Yes some people laughed, but at what cost to the mood? This ruins a potential scene for Kylo Ren to establish himself as fearsome and creates a scene for the audience to begin to associate danger with laughter, similar to Jar Jar Binks goofing around in the middle of a fire fight. My problem with the plot:Next we move on to the problem of the plot.... In that it is the same plot we have seen TWICE already. The resistance (the rebels) must defeat the First Order (empire) by blowing up the "weapon" (death star) by attacking an exposed portion with solo pilot aircraft which will lead to a system wide explosion rendering the battle station completely destroyed. Is this ringing any bells?My problem with "the weapon":The weapon is powered by SunnyD and the power of the sun.
