Despite the problems posed by bringing an entire sun into a planet and still having frozen snow on the surface, let alone any living thing not instantly being incinerated, it still takes the perfect amount of time for the rebels to win despite there being a perfect demonstration by blowing up the new republic government (a story I am left very curious about but I guess we'll never hear about it since they just get blown up). And what happens when the planet runs out of suns to use as fuel? Are there giant engines that will move it to the next sun, and can the First Order control the rotation of the planet or does gravity go all crazy when positioned to attack a new target. It must have some kind of rotation considering it is portrayed as being in orbit around some kind of sun. My problem with the character Finn: His entire role seems very forced for me. His affection for Rey is nearly immediate and he seems to be the only Stormtrooper that can aim in the entire franchise of Star Wars. He shows his prowess with a blaster during the raid of the new JJ Abrams' version of the Cantina. Killing soldiers left and right with his blaster, despite working sanitation and not firing his weapon once during his "first mission." His prowess with the lightsaber is thrown on the audience as well, defeating the Stormtrooper in close quarters combat and holding his own against the trained Kylo Ren. He is even able to use the TIE fighter's and Millennium Falcon's weapon systems with expertise, shooting down trained First Order pilots in while in both ships. My problem with the character Rey: Throughout the first portion of the movie we see her as alone, waiting for someone to come back to her, presumably her family, and only coming into contact with some other scavengers only to have a negative interaction with them. Despite this reclusive lifestyle she is able to understand what BB-8 is telling her, understand Chewbacca's language (Shriiwook), and seem to understand how the machinery in multiple ships work. My biggest problem with this character is possibly her actions. She was able to fly the Millennium Falcon flawlessly after around 15 seconds of trial and error, weaving through star destroyer wreckage and outmaneuvering the First Order's trained pilots. Also she seems to know the ship better than Han Solo himself as shown when she fixes the hyperdrive, while being portrayed as never having been in the Millennium Falcon before. Another thing, she is able to out-duel and use the force much better than the actually trained Kylo Ren. Even with training being so emphasized in the previous 6 movies she is able to defeat the feared Kylo Ren despite not even believing in the force until halfway through the movie.My problem with the character Kylo Ren: Being portrayed as the new Vader we see immediately that he is nowhere near as fearsome when instead of killing the messenger of a bad report he vents his anger out onto a control panel like a child throwing a tantrum. He finally loses all fearsome characteristics once he takes off his mask, showing that he is only a man, and a scared one at that, that bring back memories of pre-Vader Anakin Skywalker who whines his way through movies. The new Sith is shown as powerful with the force, stopping a laser blast and paralyzing two rebel fighters. But then when it is time to get information from Rey by using the force, which apparently can be used as some form of telepathy now, he is denied entry by Rey who is using the force for THE FIRST TIME IN HER LIFE! This does not show the power of Rey but merely the lack of power of Ren. Also when Kylo Ren kills his father, Han Solo, he leaves no room for redemption in his future. During the scene of Han's death the theme seems to fall upon Kylo Ren wanting redemption and to join the light side of the force, but after killing possibly the most loved character in the Star Wars universe he will find no love from the fans and if he is still alive by the end of the trilogy Disney will have needed to pull off a miracle if the fans are to accept Han's death going unavenged. My problem with the character Captain Phasma: Much like the rest of the First Order, Captain Phasma is initially portrayed as a character who will give the heroes a great deal of trouble. Eventually, during the short amount of screen time she got, she comes out looking like a wuss. She captured too easily and just agrees to the demands of the 4 rebels despite being on a base full of her loyal troops. Amazingly she agrees to turn off the most crucial aspect of the battle station's defenses. Without Captain Phasma, the rebels would have never succeeded. Her giving in so easily is surprising because she should know the risk that goes with her actions, she should have been a good soldier and made Solo, Rey, Chewy, and Finn kill her before she enables the rebels to destroy "the weapon" and possibly all of the First Order. My problem with Han Solo's death: I did not have a problem in the death of the character but rather in how it was handled. Han Solo is arguably the most loved character in the franchise and should be given a proper send off if he is to be killed off. I never got that from this movie. Han's death seems to be brushed aside for the sake of focusing more on Finn and Rey's story. There is never really screen time dedicated to dwell on the loss of everyone's favorite scoundrel. A quick look between Rey and Leia is all we get. One would think that there would be some ceremony for a hero of the rebellion but that just would not fit into the new jovial Star Wars. At least Qui-Gon got a funeral and he was only in one movie of the franchise but a fan-favorite completing his fourth movie barely gets 30 seconds of characters mourning for him. I was conflicted on what emotions JJ Abrams wanted me to feel exiting the movie. Of course I was still sad at the loss of Han and with no real closure or time to mourn him I stayed sad for the rest of the movie, meanwhile the tone shifted to one of hopefulness as Rey finds Luke (much easier than the movie made it seem it would be) and starts her training. Hopefulness and sadness are emotions that do not easily mix, though one could make the argument that I could feel sad for Han's death and hopeful that Rey will beat the Sith but she already did that. And since the rebels seem to have already beat the First Order I am left not knowing what to be hopeful for and feeling sad at the same time.My problem with the "epic duel": When it comes time to see the final duel at the end of the movie we have a matchup between the evil Kylo Ren against the two heroes, Rey and Finn. Kylo Ren is clearly hurt from a blaster as he took a blast from Chewbacca's crossbow but he demonstrates the ability to endure the pain and function regularly as he beats his wound repeatedly. What is expected is a complete massacre of a deserted soldier and a scavenger but what the audience gets is the opposite. Of course the good guys must win eventually but they do not need to win in the first movie of the newest trilogy. In both previous trilogies, successful or not, we see our hero attempt to face off against the villain and lose. This happened in the cases of Qui-Gon against Darth Maul in The Phantom Menace, Anakin and Obi-Wan against Count Dooku in Attack of the Clones, Yoda against Darth Sidious in Revenge of the Sith, and finally Luke Skywalker against Darth Vader in The Empire Strikes Back. These losses happened for a reason, to show that the hero is not yet ready to defeat the evil that opposes him/her. It gives added fear toward the main villain and shows how powerful he is. The idea of a Jedi training to gain skill has been stressed so much in the previous 6 movies the thought of even a novice Jedi defeating a Sith Lord would be absurd. But in Star Wars 7 we do not only see a scavenger beat a Sith, but we also see an ex-Stormtrooper hold his own against the "fury" of Kylo Ren. Having the new Darth Vader figure be beaten by a scavenger who has never wielded a lightsaber, never had any combat training against trained soldiers, and did not even believe in the force until halfway into the movie extremely belittles his ability to bring any concern to the audience over the danger of their hero. During the next movies we will possibly see Rey or another main character face off against Kylo Ren again. Now at the end of the movie we see Ren go to complete his training (I have no idea why he was in charge if his training was incomplete) but we also see Rey find Luke and begin her training. By Star Wars 8 both will have improved but one would think Rey would have improved exponentially due to her absolute lack of training during her entire life. We will have a face-off in later in the series that we have already seen, with no added tension because we there will not be much doubt about our hero due to Kylo Ren already being brutally defeated in Star Wars 7. Why are there still rebels?  It has been 20 years since the destruction of the empire and a new republic has been created. Usually when a rebel force overthrows a government they become the governing body and cease to be rebels, creating a capital and government to rule in. One would think that after the rebels create a new government that they would at least move their base to the planet where their new government is. So why do the rebels still exist in this movie? Also, why does this new republic allow the creation of a new death star? They must have clearly understood what was going on because it is hard to build or modify an entire planet without the ruling government finding out. And still nothing happens. No one remembered a few decades ago when an entire planet was destroyed and clearly no precautions have been enacted to stop this type of attack from happening again. But hey, everyone seems to love the lack of originality. At the end I was left searching for anything to like about this movie (I really wanted to like it), anything that would give me a decent overall feeling about the film, like the fight between Darth Maul, Qui-Gon and Obi-Wan with Dual of the Fates ringing in the background. But even the film score left me wanting something much better. Unless someone can convince me there is something to like about the movie besides less than 3 minutes of cool X-wing vs TIE-fighter action and a few Easter eggs, this movie will take its place as the 7th best in the franchise in my mind.

I will say this about the movie, it is entertaining. And when compared to some bad movies out there, this isn't necessarily a bad movie, overall it is very well done, the sound is great, the visuals, the effects, even the acting is good.However, when taken in the context of Star Wars, this just does not feel like a star wars movie, the pace is completely wrong, the characters are flat and basically rehashes of previous characters from the saga. There is just no sense of accomplishment anywhere, it is as if the plot just moves along, there is no sense of struggle for the heroes, everything just conveniently happens. I went in with fairly low expectations, so in some ways I was pleasantly surprised, but I left disappointed overall. It is better than the prequels, but not by much. This movie really is just Ep IV, V, and VI rolled into one, with a female Luke Skywalker.

Besides watching Harrison Ford and some of the humour, this is much of a fans movie. Nothing really stand out, not in any of the action or fight scenes, the space ship, environment, or special effect. As for the story, it's pretty linear and it leaves A LOTS of "unanswered questions" which is pretty much a setup for the upcoming StarWars episode in 2017, another in 2018, and another one... until no one remember about the force....

This was a super-hyped, lukewarm imitation of the original Star Wars movie. Whole scenes have been lifted and re-imagined for a new audience. It's two and a half hours of my life I'll never get back. Couldn't have been more disappointed..

I really looked forward to seeing this new Star Wars film. However all I got was a weak rehash of the 1977 Star wars. Sure the effects were better and the music was great but the story was too close to the same. I was never emotionally invested in the new characters like the original. I hope the next attempts will be more creative.
Just a copy of Episodes IV, V and VI, rolled into a single film.
The casting is perfect. Huge investment in special effects. But the story is poor. It does not contribute anything new except a nostalgic joy.
This was a horrible movie. I am stunned so many people liked it. Disney must have paid off some critics.
Unoriginal plot, poor characters but at least it looked good. Unless something special happens with the next films you may as well stick with watching the original trilogy.
It is A New Hope, only bigger. but nothing new or creative.

There were some bright spots with the new characters and the new plot lines which you can look for online, however, there were too many ideas carried over, plagiarized, from the original trilogy.The movie relied too much on nostalgia and was a poor attempt at a reboot of a franchise and is nothing more than a transitional movie to steer you into the next movie.Stop me if you've heard any of these facts before. All of which are in this movie.rescue from a Star Destroyer prison on a .Guy gets tossed in the garbage chute.Droids crash on a planet pursued by dark jediThis isn't the droid you're looking for.X-wing fighter destroys the 3rd Death star.btw, there's another death star.Good jedi turns to the dark sideHis mother utters the words "I know there is still good in him, because I've felt it"Major character death at the hands of a dark jedi

Kind of dissappointing, a lot of hype surrounds this film but the body of the film seemed kinda just slapped together. Example: at one moment you're like yeah this bad guy is definitely tough next second nah just kidding.. Great visual effects but lacks depth.

It's pretty entertaining, but I think it is because people are just really upset with Episode 1, 2, and 3. Because if you really paid attention, you'll realize this is actually a remake of Episode IV.

JJ Abrams has gotten old, his tired movies are not good anymore. This was basically just a remake of the original movie if everyone got older and history together. my problem with this movie is the drama is just not good the plot lines are very thin, there is no depth there at all. I liked the original star wars IV but this left a horrible taste in my mouth. Unfortunately I may be done with the star wars series forever.

It's been a few days since I seen the movie. In the time I decided to drop my score another half a star. While I did enjoy this film for the most part. Much more than the previous installments, Episodes 1, 2, and 3. There are huge glaring flaws to this movie that really hurt it's potential to be more enjoyable. Biggest being the huge lack of chemistry among the cast. I found myself wishing that both Harrison Ford and Carrie Fisher were not in this film. They looked and felt absolutely uncomfortable whenever they had scenes together. While I found Rey to be a very likable character, someone I am truly interested in seeing where she goes in the future. I hope that future does not include the character of Finn. Boyega is another actor that didn't seem to have chemistry with the other actors, and that is not mentioning that this character was very poorly written. He was this movie's Jar Jar Binks, though not quiet as annoying, but getting there. Another peeve, too many references, hints and copying of Episode 4, there were moments when this felt as if it were a remake rather than continuation. We need more original ideas writers. As for Kylo Ren, the temper tantrums left me perplexed, really didn't add anything to the story, seemed like something that should have hit the cutting room floor in my opinion. My favorite things taken from this more were Rey (Daisy Ridley), BB8 ( had most of the successful humorous parts ), and the ending of the movie. Loved the ending, and left me very curious to see where the Skywalkers go in the next movie.

Horrible unoriginal movie, which solely builds on nostalgia for the original trilogy, while ironically taking a crap on all the accomplishments of our heroes in Episode VI. As soon as the hype dies down this movie will be recognized for the cinematic faecal matter it is.

Star Wars: The franchise rebooted is a very safe by the numbers movie that did not excite me at all and this is a movie which I had low expectations for to begin with. Now, I might get some flack for this but let me explain why.Minor SpoilersBasically, the movie is a new hope re-packaged. Nothing has changed in the galaxy, except the Empire is has become vestigial and the old cast of the original trilogy ended up being a bunch screw ups that managed to get everything back to the same condition as a new hope. It's like watching the new spiderman reboot. Guys, I really don't need to watch uncle Ben die for the second time. The acting: The original cast.It was okay, it was nice to see Harrison play Han again. He even manages to put a performance that is slightly better than his performance as Indy Jones. Though, as character arc, having old Han Solo in the same spot as New Hope Han is quite disheartening. Carrie Fisher Leia is also a tragic figure, she is relegated to the role of Mon Mothma as Ms. Exposition mixed in with disheartened mom who for having the rank of general does very little commanding, that shit is taken by Admiral Ackbar.Mark Hamill Luke is barely in the movie as sequel bait. The only ones that didn't show their age was C3PO and Chewbacca. R2-D2 had one tiny part to play as he was shown up by the volleyball robot.The villains:New Darth Vader/Kylo Ren: Is a laughable villain, they managed to resurrected all the cringe worthy moments of Anakin Skywalker, with an actor that cannot play a torn soul and whose actions are so inept that new emperor should have killed him.New Emperor/Supreme Leader: Again a mere shadow of the menace that was Emperor Palpatine. Also poor Andy Serkis will be cursed to play CGI motion capture model for the rest of his career. He also just there as sequel bait.Quota Stormtrooper/Phasma: Why did they feel the need to waste Brianne of Tarth on this. She is NPC with like two lines and no reason to be there plot wise. She isn't even like a super Stormtrooper. WTF. Even gets captured.New Tarkin/Hux: Surprisingly manages to halfway steal the show, though his whole purpose was to be a Hitler knockoff. Just missing the mustache.The heroes:Reverse Darth Vader/Finn: Is not too bad, though I wish the story was a little more developed. Would have been nice to see him in the Stormtrooper role for a little longer and fuller arc to heroNew Luke/Rey: Again not too bad, thankfully sparing me" I'm female hero so that means I'm a mega bitch" to very minor levels which is actually is joke in the movie. Kind of wooden and also lacking development.New Han sorta/Po: Is missing from about half of the movie and is relegated to hand wave plot motion device that is actually quite sad.Minor charactersNew Yoda/Maz: A full-fledged alien Ms. Exposition who sole purpose is to push New Luke to Old Luke.The effects: Were good, if the camera work didn't excite. Thankfully, someone told JJ to knock it off with the lens flairs. The soundtrack: Classic John Williams, though there wasn't any Imperial March or Duel of Fates to speak of, it's kind of sad really.Finally, I'm pretty sure this movie is going to get high marks from everybody else cuz politics and money yo but my from my humble opinion Hollywood managed to make another cash grab by resurrecting storyline Frankenstein's monster style yet again. Not that the movie is prequel bad, just nothing new to see and no new story to tell.

Horrible, horrible movie. Filled with cliche moments, plot holes, some things didn't make any absolute sense, too many sudden moments where characters meet up , the main "heroine" is a feminist propaganda mary-sue ,this is a FAIL of desperately trying to copy something from old movies but he copied the ENTIRE PLOT... JJ should be banned from producing anything in the future, he tried to mask our eyes with fancy WOW moments and cgi but that is all.. who gave this guy right to be a producer ? the whole movie industry is going slowly down the drain because of this, it's been like that for the past decade... 93% ? I guess the reviewers here got their pockets filled up to give positive opinions. I am terribly scared for the future of movie industry.

Most telling part of this movie: They forgot that C3PO has a silver leg. "Big Deal" you say. Well, yeah, so what? Just explain it away. He got a new one. He has a crazy Red Arm, anyway! So cool! Maybe he found a new, identical, C3PO droid leg. But wait a minute. We have to do that a lot in this movie. We have to make up our own plot explanations 20 or 30 times. OH, yeah.. that *could* have happened, whatever. A jawa trader just gave up a droid that's worth a fortune, sure, but he probably didn't know it was worth anything either. The bad guy took his mask off because some stupid smuggler pissed him off, sure. Princess Leia hugs Rey as if she's her long-lost daughter even though they've exchanged six words with each other. Poe and Fin are super duper best buddies even though right before they escaped, Poe pointed out that this guy is just a stormtrooper who wants to desert. But whatever, best friends now. We have to do that a lot, and it is annoying. Do all of the reviewers work for Disney? How does this have 8.5/10 rating?.There are two movies here. There's a really intriguing story about a girl who finds out that she has a deep, mysterious history that she never knew about, and rebel friends with a plan to bring freedom to a universe ruled by power and greed. And then there's a Hollywooded-out story where a bunch of characters that were almost really cool got left flat and the plot elements had to be resolved when the bad guy loses his super powers, the good guys suddenly gain unexplained super powers, and where the bad guy's base is really poorly defended and his minions easily beaten.I didn't hate it. Seriously. But it's hard not to hate the viral marketing (What's with those "No Spoilers!" memes ?? What is there to spoil? Are you afraid I'm going to tell my friends about the obvious plot holes?) This movie was sort of a cash grab. If it didn't have "Star Wars" all over it, it would be just another crappy Hollywood movie.The Plot Had Obvious ProblemsThe plot elements resolved themselves far too easily, and a lot of what happened did not make sense in the context of the Star Wars universe. One character's powers are "awakened" in the space of about twenty minutes - suddenly more powerful than other Jedi that have trained for years. The bad guy suddenly loses his powers for no reason. A janitor gives someone who is basically a kung-fu master a run for his money. The giant, quadzillion space-dollar space station has an obvious weakness and terrible network security, since its defenses can be deactivated by a random squad commander at a random, unguarded computer terminal. Wtf?There are dozens of moments that just don't make sense, which would have been *so easy* to just change slightly so the plot is a bit more intriguing. It all makes me think that the movie was named this just so they had a magical explanation for all of the ridiculously good luck that the heroes have.The Dialogue Fell Short -The lines seemed like they had been oversimplified to just a series of one-liners, which in most cases would make sense with just a bit more dialogue. The science and realism that could've easily been there, wasn't - it became clear that the writers don't respect the audience when they say "*the* sun" rather than "a star," or "this system's sun," or really, anything other than what they actually said, which sounded completely stupid. Another phrase I take issue with is "thermal oscillator." Semantically, that makes no sense. It would have been just as easy to say "thermal modulator." But, they didn't. And that upsets me.The plot is a bunch of recycled, generic Star Wars elements, yes. But, that said, it's hard to say what I would've been satisfied with. There is a lot that they could have messed up with this movie, or the next one.#1 Problem with the movie - The really cool, really intriguing bad guy takes off his mask. He apparently had gone through great pains to hide his face, and make the audience think he was awesome. In the first half of the movie, he's this awesome, violent masked character with a cool voice. In the second half of the movie, he's an insecure child whose force powers shut off by themselves for no reason. Ooh, I'm so scared.The point is, this movie could have been *so cool.* I think they should have gone with the plot that it's obvious they were trying to have. But somewhere along the lines, Hollywood happened to this movie and they decided to please the crowd by throwing all three of the previous episodes in a blender, and removing any really distinguishing plot elements from this film. Whatever. It was fun to watch, but nothing happened, and the real hero of the movie is a nameless X-ray pilot. On the surface, it looks really good, but I think that if you scratch the glass, this is a really generic Hollywood story with a bunch of Star Wars stickers on it.
horrible, reductive, ruins the original trilogy by turning beloved heroes into complete failures. if you are a fan don't watch it.

Jar Jar Abrhams has finally proved what the hardcore Star Wars fans thought wasn't possible. He made a movie so bad it makes Episode 1 look good. The movie is essentially a reboot of Episode 4. From a bigger deathstar (which the movie points our for you incase you weren't sure) to the death of a mentor which causes the main character to cry despite having met him only a few scenes earlier. This movie was bogus. Incase that isn't enough we even get a whinney tantrum throwing sith to enjoy. The humor was so randomly thrown in the movie that I wasn;t sure if I'm supposed to laugh or just stare awkwardly at the screen. They tried to make the Empire funny which made the movie even worse since the empire is supposed to be forboading and dangerous while the Rebellion tends to lean to more humanly charecteristics. As for the Rebellion they added it to this movie, but its called the "Resistance". They even have a bunker ust like in Episode 4 even though they won 30 years earlier. Theres not explenation as to why the Resistance isn't the Republic or as to why the Republic isn't helping the Resistance or why theres even a Resistance anyways. As for the "New Order" there isn't much explenation as to why it's around or why the REpublic lets it do it's thing and build massive planet sized Death Stars. I could go on and on, but if you're a hardcore fan and haven't seen this movie yet..don't waste 10 bucks on a ticket. Instead sit at home and watch A New Hope. Its the same thing anyways.

The new Star Wars (The Force Awakens) people over reacted with it saying how great it was but although the actors were amazing the plot wasn't. Even the directer from the first 3 movies even said he would have done it different. In the first book is shows you tat when Luke Skywalker found out he had the force he had to learn how to use a life saver, and the mind control like thing. Now I don't know if you noticed but the new character Rey as soon as she found out she had the force she completely knew how to use everything, from the mind control, to how to use a lifesaver.

The film was more about visuals and has some really dumb moments through out and J.J. Abrams penchant to make fan fiction films. The problem for me was that Rey character at times was poorly written. inconstant, and annoying character I have seen. She speaks lines I would expect a ten year old sidekick to say in awe or some star wars fan would spew in fan fiction . Yes my eyes were rolling like they were watching the Phantom Menace when Rey was suddenly starts piloting the Millennium Falcon (plot hole) at the beginning and then Han Solo's later entrance in another ship that finds them (plot hole). I can see why Rian Johnson is taking over the franchise for Episode 8. I hope Riany fixes the characters and this franchise that has been repeatably trashed by Lucas.

RETREAD, RETREAD, RETREAD. This is a compendium of prior star wars movies nothing new here at all. I've seen them all. Asked the kids,(high school and college) what they thought, "retread, retread, retread". For those of you die hard entrained Star Wars fans this will be manna but looking at it critically, nothing new. Bored. At least I won't have to watch Harrison Ford again in episode 8. I think I'll just watch that one on redbox.
It's a very nostalgic and fun movie. It was precisely what everyone expected with the story plot, that's it. It wasn't one of those films that will keep you on the edge of your seat, well for me.
Noise is a poor substitute for plot or character development. Lots of retreaded views/sequences from the '77 original. Wait for Red Box.

I can't believe the Tomatometer score of 93% as of today. As someone who saw all the episodes of Star Wars, in the order that they were released I am shocked. I wouldn't give " The Force Awakens" even two stars, one and a half at best, poor scripting, poor directing, poor casting and poor acting by some of the leads. What more could you NOT want in a film series that is considered iconic by generations of viewers.

I thought Star Wars - The Force Awakens was terrible. They ruined the star wars franchise. Actors and acting was just atrocious. Story and plot was boring and not believable at all. I really don't like how it took Luke Skywalker three movies (including training by Yoda) before he could use/handle the force and defeat Darth Vader, but it takes this girl 14 seconds (with no training) to figure out and master all the nuances of the force and defeat the dark side/Kylo Ren. She went from scavenger/nobody to the ultimate jedi warrior in 14 seconds with no training. Just ridiculous and stupid. She is not believable as a hero/jedi saving the galaxy and Kylo Ren is not believable as the bad guy (new Darth Vader) - he's a wuss. I'm surprised they did not have him break down and cry and surrender to the girl. Terrible job as a villain. I won't bother going to see any more Star Wars movies now that Disney is doing them.

Great visuals (as you'd expect) and some fantastic action sequences but the film overall is let down by some horrible and frankly unforgivable plot holes that caused me to lower my rating considerably. Having said that I still enjoyed the film and would recommend others seeing it, just prepare to be disappointed if you are unable to suspend belief and can't just go with the flow and accept it for what it is.

Really just a rehash of the original episode with too much reliance on the original characters. Even the special effects were not all that impressive compared to the incredible "newness" of the special effects in the original. Good, but not great.

Power of the Mouse. This sodden remake of a 1977 is limpid at best. The acting is atrocious, the plot is thinner than a Paris model and the special effects are tepid. The only black guy character is, guess what, a garbage collector (disclosure- I'm an old white guy). This turkey is so bad than even Harrison Ford killed himself. Did I mention Princess Lameo?
It's a remake of the first movie (1977) mixed with nostalgia and a dash of twilight.I like the footage, but the story sucks.

As I was watching the movie, I enjoyed it. J.J. Abrams recaptures the tone, music, and effects of the original movie. Too bad it doesn't have an original bone in its body, except the Kylo Ren subplot. Hopefully the other two sequels have the balls to be more original.

Apparently the world was so desperate for a period piece romance, that they saw one without the name "Nicholas Sparks" attached and swooned. Two good performances by Ronan and Cohen and a decent ending can't erase a rushed relationship and standard narrative. No.... seriously. Every "big" event between Ellis and Tony left me saying "Already????" and the second half is even worse. Don't believe the hype.

Saoirse (sur-sha) was good in this, but otherwise it was pretty a standard 50's immigrant period piece film. i really don't get why it's at a 98% rotten tomatoes score, why it's nominated for best picture, or why everyone is crying when it's over. *shrugs*
A nice movie and story, however it moved so damn slow. Saoirse Ronan was super cute and did an awesome job, but I don't think she will win for best actress this year.
More waste of good bandwidth

Saoirse (sur-sha) was good in this, but otherwise it was pretty a standard 50's immigrant period piece film. i really don't get why it's at a 98% rotten tomatoes score, why it's nominated for best picture, or why everyone is crying when it's over. *shrugs*

I like a good period piece, which I guess this was, but I cant buy that the woman whose character was defined by directness and honesty would string along her Irish suitor. And if Mrs. Kelly hadnt been a bitch to her, would she have still decided to fess up?
Homesickness is like most sicknesses. It will pass.
Great performances, beautifully shot.. but incredibly slow and boring.
The overwrought parade of stereotypes was enough for me to give up about half way through. yikes. "I-talyun fud is da best in da woyuld"... ugh.

The only redeeming quality of this movie was the performance of Ms. Ronan. The rest was an empty plot, a badly-written script, and no real character development. I had high expectations for this Oscar-nominated film, but was left feeling frustrated by the naivety and pointlessness of the movie. Save your two hours for something more interesting.

So, somebody found out that Saoirse Ronan could imitate the accent of her family quite well and gave her a stage to show it off. This is a slushy love story where hardly anything worthy of a film happens. How this has recieved so many Oscar nominations, I'll never know. It really shouldn't win any.

I'm not sure what I thought this movie was going to be, but it wasn't that. Saoirse Ronan is a dream, but the movie is a snooze. I'm sure it's better than a Lifetime movie, but that's what it felt like to me.

First and foremost, Ronan is very solid in her Oscar-nominated lead performance. However, the film as a whole felt underwhelming for me. It starts with the promising premise of this girl struggling to accept love, and dealing with the hardships of being homesick and the overall struggle for immigrants in the '50's. However, heading into the second and third acts, the film falls into a very routine, "I love him but I'm almost tempted by another lover" plot device and without anything new to add to that kind of story. The film also begins with a wonderful light and quirky tone, only again to be sucked into the cliches of this romance plot, but without giving you any stakes into caring if it'll all work out. Overall Brooklyn isn't a bad, but not an overwhelmingly special movie.

Not a fan of how she decides to go back to US. Being married, and spent so many time dating the "catch" back home just seems so fucking wrong. You can argue that she isn't sleeping around but it is still so fucked up. In China, we call girls like this green tea bitxx. So when her previous employer talked to her and "reminded" her of her marriage status, suddenly she decides to go back to US? The Fxxx? This can be handled a lot better. The rest of the film is beautiful in a lot of ways.

Great acting and filming. Too bad the story line is so transparently contrived and predictable. It all boils down to a classic "chick-flick," though one of the very best productions ever of that unctuous genre. One telling reaction from theater audiences: While a few attempts at humor drew well earned laughs from everyone, most were yawners...yet evoked raucous -- and solely female -- laughter.
I don't understand how this could be considered an award winning movie. It was sweet, the costumes were good. But it was nothing exceptional.
Brooklyn's heart wrenching drama may feel too manipulative and depressing, but it's mostly redeemed by a talented cast and a large degree of thoughtfulness
Seems this fits the trend of me not liking oscar nominated movies. There was no real conflict. Who meets and gets married like that?
Not bad until the last chapter were it all felt rushed. It had masterpiece potential but the story failed in the end leaving me emotionally untouched and not interested.

Boring.Facile acting and technical work don't make this trite and dull story better than what it is.The period setting is generally wasted as it barely engages it - nothing more than eye-candy for our culture's period-fetish. The character of Tony the Italian Plumber is so on the nose, he plays like a joke. So does his loud-mouthed little brother.Audiences eat this up because ultimately they're starved for films that depict a simple, positive story. That doesn't make this film good though. More a reflection of our deprived culture than anything else.

if you enjoy love stories on the Hallmark channel, you will like this film. The acting is well done. This is clearly not my style of movie and I cannot understand the oscar buzz on the film. Also the main character is meant to be "charming" but I found her to be a jerk.

This movie was awful; I don't understand the high rating. Synopsis: A super boring Irish girl moves to Brooklyn and marries a sweet Italian dude. Then her sister drops dead for absolutely no apparent reason, prompting her to go back to Ireland for a month, where she ignores her husband's letters, dates some rich Irish dude, and pretends she isn't married because ~she's conflicted~ and ~her heart is complicated~... But wait! Nevermind! Ireland sucks! So Boring goes back to Brooklyn to be with the husband she ignored for a month like nothing happened, and he's basically like, "Omg, I have no questions about any of this. Let's kiss in the street."I should have seen Star Wars for the third time.

Cute but not much else. I suppose it has some interesting and nice moments, about homesickness and finding your confidence, but I wasn't particularly compelled by anybody and I disliked how they tended to jump cut out of any large bits of dialogue. All in all, a very sweet and endearing movie but felt emotionally reserved to me. You never get a real sense of Tony so I didn't feel like she would have lost out. I'd say the lesson I learned was "don't marry the first guy you meet."

I just don't get it. This movie had good performances and gorgeous cinematography. It had a potentially good plot. But it was SO slow. I looked at my watch probably 20 times. The people i saw it with actually hated it. Just don't get the critics on this one. 98%? On such a poorly paced movie? If you're thinking about seeing this movie, wait till it comes out on DVD. Then at least you can pause the film and take a little nap while it slowly lulls you to sleep.

Lovely film. Acting was wonderful. Story was interesting. Storyline was good too. So whats the problem? In a nutshell . . .I don't see how Eliish (Ronan) lost her viginity to Cohen so quickly. It was a beautiful story up until that point. It was like jumping from 1950 straight into Tinder 2016. Is the author of the book a male?? Oh, maybe thats why. A man writing a book about a young Irish girl or any girl usually ends up losing her virginity right? And I thing her Italian boyfriend/husband could have been a better actor and taller. Ok, thats it in a nutshell. Too bad, it really could have been a delightful story without the trash.

A very "old-fashioned" movie. If it had been filmed in b&w it could have been mistaken for a 40's flick. It had a number of touching moments and a little surprise when she returns for a supposedly "short" visit back to the Emerald Isle But it took "forever" for something interesting to happen. Patience and revererence for great production values and fine acting are the keywords here.

Dull story, and misleading trailer. She is probably the luckiest immigrant ever and she is a bad person being married and still leading the other guy on. Only good is the pictures. Performance is okay. No idea why it got such good reviews. Maybe it is just me but I can't related to this movie as an immigrant myself.

With all the big action movies sometimes a simple film done well can have just as big an impact, as any action movie, which is shown in the film "Brooklyn". If you want a story with ton's of action and drama this would not be in your selection but if you want a film that is poignant and even poetic at times "Brooklyn" might be your stop.
Safely told tale of 1950s immigration and love. It's good, but pretty simple. Maybe that's OK, but it could have been much more.
Cliched romantic premise but solid old-fashioned melodrama.

I actually couldn't sit all the way through this movie. For the first hour I was in love with it, but when she returns to Ireland she totally went out of character, which lost me and just made me decide to get up and leave. I think I may've missed something. I thought she'd married her boyfriend before she went back to Ireland. I know I saw them in the waiting room at the courthouse, and the clerk came out and paged them, but I don't actually remember them getting married. Did I miss something and she actually backed out at the last minute? I know that she seemed to be 'all in' on the relationship, so backing out doesn't make sense. Alas no instant replay at the movies, and I'm not quite willing to buy another ticket to find out. In any event I thought she was already married by the time she went back to Ireland, in which case her behavior there seemed to be totally incongruous with the first hour of the movie. Assuming she was married, the fact that she didn't mention it to friends and family sort of turned the movie into an episode of Three's Company for me; rather mindless and stupid. I was so dazed and confused by the behavior, I decided I needed to get up and stretch my legs, which led to me just going ahead and leaving the theatre.I will give the film all its kudos for great cast and filming. And the first hour was a very interesting exploration of the nicer side of humanity. The old bat that runs the irish store where Eilis is working when the film opens reminded me of my own Irish grandmother who was just as bigoted, opinionated and nasty. That bell rang true.

Brooklyn stands on even footing with Saoirse Ronan's impeccable performance. It's the kind of film that has everything in place from start to finish, so much so that its ending is predictable and its dilemma is barely large enough to pull too many heartstrings. Overall, its impact is not what it should be.
Romance with paid immigration and job training. Very PBSish. The third act conflict alone is worth a bowl of Lucky Charms soaked in chloroform.
I felt heart strings being pulled, pulling me right out of the theater with this overly trying to be good and boring everyone in the process !

You know the reason why I saw this. If you don't, then figure it out. Anyway, this was a really good drama movie. Saoirse Ronan stars the main character who moves to Brooklyn to start a new life. She does a fantastic job in role. This wasn't here best movie but it wasn't the worst either. I was the youngest person in the theater when I went to see it. It's a good drama and I recommend it to seniors. This movie was very Irish so be ready for an Irish themed throughout the movie.
Great performances from Ronan and Cohen, but feels too much like a movie skipping through the pages of a novel and ending up only telling the surface of the story.

Colm Toibin is a great writer. Nick Hornby is not. I have enjoyed some of C.T.'s novels a great deal (In fact "The Heather Blazing" is a favourite of mine.) I like his genteel style in such work. The performances here are fine, or better than fine; it looks lovely: the colour palette, the costumes, the scenes and scenery all make for a fine backdrop. Where it fails, and it is a major failing, is that it says nothing of any real worth about the migrant experience. Eilis (Saoirise Ronan) is shipped off to NYC through the assistance of her thoughtful sister and a kindly priest. (In a good performance by Jim Broadbent as Father Flood.) Up until an easily predicted plot development the difficulties faced by our heroine are a bout of seasickness, the need for 30 seconds training in her new job as a shop assistant, and a touch of homesickness. While I'm happy to see women succeed, there would have been far more dirt under the fingernails of all of these women. Apart from the minor matter of losing her virginity, Eilis could indeed be the sainted mother of God. It all suffers from Nick Hornby blandness. Everything he touches turns to bland. My advice: stay away from his cooking and, more importantly, his "creative" projects. This is not meant to be an art house atmospheric enigma, nor is it, but it fails to involve solely because of a threadbare plot that avoids detailing the threadbare aspects of lives led by women who were, in reality, the working poor.
Sugary pablum. Good acting but ultimately not much going on.

I don't see why this got high ratings at all. It is low class acting, and your mind does not have to think at all. It is a high school level movie. Wasted my money today. Go see In the Heart of the Sea instead of this crap.

I made a rotten tomatoes account just to help good souls avoid this terrible piece of flotsam that washed up to NYC's harbors. If you took 50 lbs of marzipan, crammed it into a Hallmark card, and send it direct to DVD, you'd have something close to the cloying, piece of dried-up-make-up-foundation that this movie is. What in the heck is WRONG with people that you could actually like this thing?? It has NOTHING in it! NOTHING happens! Some fake, terrible deus ex machina plot-thing happens in the middle, and then just floats away, just as it came. SPOILER ALERTIrish girl falls in love with Italian boy. And........ nothing happens. We're talking middle-school movie day, the last week of school, that kind of movie. It's an insult to the hard work the Irish did when they came to NYC. It's an insult to the difficulties that immigrants faced. This is a time in our country when we need honest reflections into that time in our history. That's what art/music/film is for. THIS crap is an insult to our country, our history, the Irish, and the genre of cheesy films. My trust in Rotten Tomatoes is rocked, by the 98% ratings.

It is undeniably well-executed, and Ronan's performance is excellent, but there isn't anything that really sets it apart. While it manages to mostly avoid romance cliches, the scenes that should be gut-punching remain fairly unaffecting. It does have its charm, and it is basically impossible to dislike, but it's fairly mundane and ordinary.

I have absolutely no idea why this film got 98% (8.6) in Rotten Tomatoes, not a single damn idea. This film is terribly predictable, characters and plots were terribly under-developed, and the message is terribly simple and naive (in short, the equally terrible trailer of this film already spoiled the WHOLE film, not a single surprise left). Even the much-praised role by Saoirse Ronan felt terribly short (in comparison with her sublime presence in "Atonement" almost ten years ago), nothing surprising, nothing breakthrough from the role. Of course, the film's optimism is much appreciated, especially in the context of a new USA where immigrants are no longer "liked" or a new Europe where immigrants are no longer "welcome". Thus, I absolutely do not hate this film. Its simplicity only wasted my time (yes, that is simplicity, not cinematic minimalism or any similar euphemism).
To be fair, this is a properly made, decent piece.Those overwhelming credit, from the film itself to Saoirse Ronan's acting, sound rather exaggerating however.
It was very slow and boring. Took me twice to finish watching it because I lost interest. Doesn't belong in the cinema, maybe lifetime.

Apparently the world was so desperate for a period piece romance, that they saw one without the name "Nicholas Sparks" attached and swooned. Two good performances by Ronan and Cohen and a decent ending can't erase a rushed relationship and standard narrative. No.... seriously. Every "big" event between Ellis and Tony left me saying "Already????" and the second half is even worse. Don't believe the hype.

A very charming, old-fashioned melodrama with a glowing performance by Saoirse Ronan. I simply can't say what's so special about her performance but maybe it's the sense of a Hollywood Golden Age leading lady.

I really thought that I was going to enjoy this movie more than I actually did. I thought I was going to give it at least four stars, but sadly it only really lands on three stars for me. I loved the book that this movie is based on and I got emotional just by reading the movie's reviews, which made me think that I would be just as attached with the movie as I was with the book. Sadly I don't feel as optimistic towards this movie as everyone else seems to be feeling. I felt that the movie never really began and there were a lot of things that were left out in the beginning that needed to be there to fully comprehend the movie if you haven't already read the book. I have always said that I think Saoirse Ronan is the best actress of her generation and I don't think I'll ever change my mind on that one, this movie will probably result in Saoirse Ronan receiving her second Academy Award nomination, but I was still not as blown away by her performance as I was expecting. For me this movie was a bit too slow, it was difficult to get into it and there was never really anything that glued me to the screen. There were a few scenes that were missing that needed to be there and there were other scenes that were in the movie that didn't feel quite as important. Sometimes it felt like the scenes were jumping from scene to scene and I didn't always feel like it was telling a coherent story. All in all it wasn't a bad movie, it just could have been a lot better, and like most movies starring Saoirse Ronan she really did lift the movie to a higher level than what it would have been otherwise.
A very slow character study of an immigrant who travels from Ireland to America and her modest life and everyday experiences.

This has to rate as the most boring movie of the year. The old "boy-meets-girl" story unfolds like the slow boat from Ireland to Brooklyn. It's all predictable and Saoirse Ronan sleep walks through it with a wooden performance that adds to the soporific effect. Emory Cohen is the only sign of life in a vibrant supporting role as the nice Italian boy (and he does look a bit young for the part) who wins Ms. Ronan's heart, hastily marries her, loses her, and you can guess the sappy ending (yawn).
Its OK. Surprisingly has not much to do with Brooklyn since most of it takes place in Ireland. Just mediocre.
Kind of a hollow story of a girl split between New York and home. I was looking for more from this.
This is not the 50''s Brooklyn I knew. It's a small love story that could have been set anywhere. Wish they'd used an Italian to play one. Where were Nathan's, Junior's, A&S and other landmarks?

A slow and sensitive look at the immigrant experience. However it lost me half way through.SPOILER:I lost my ability to identify with our protagonist on her return to Ireland.Her failure to reveal her marital status caused unnecessary pain in others

A young Irish woman leaves her mom and sister behind and travels to America seeking a better life where she quickly gets over being homesick, finds a good job and falls in love with and marries the first person she dates; but when she returns to Ireland to comfort her mother after the tragic death of her sister, she is tempted with a job and new man, until she is confronted that she is married and so she returns home to her true love. The End. Seriously?

This film had so much potential but, ultimately, I found it disappointing. The cast was excellent, the leading lady a great and charming actor, the cinematography gorgeous (if a bit dewy eyed and sentimental). But the plot was this film's downfall. I thought it was great until it became a melodramatic love triangle. A Hollywood film with beautiful young people and a love triangle; who would have thunk it? At that point it became predictable, not in the sense of knowing what choice the heroine would make but rather in the sense that I didn't care. Perhaps it's because we live in narcissistic times that none of the critics seemed to notice, let alone care, that this woman who was portrayed as so lovely, so sweet, so kind behaved in ways that belied that impression. She was not truthful with two men who were falling over themselves for her, leaving one to wonder if she would ever return and not thinking to tell the other she was married and then breaking it off the courageous way, by dropping a letter through the door. (I think the second guy was the lucky one.) She mistreated her mother when she left without even 24 hours notice. She mistreated a house-mate by finding a way to ditch her. Everything was all about her wants, her needs, her love of Ireland, her distaste for the narrow mindedness of small-town life. One might think no one else existed, really. Lesser characters were mere plot devices in a film that was all about just one character. I'm still giving it three stars because of the film's strengths. But it was nowhere near as good as it might have been with a more thoughtful, less cliched, script.
I never fully connected with the characters, and while charmed was not awe-struck

3 out of 5 stars. Excellent performance by Saoirse Ronan, who has been impressive since 13 years old in "Atonement." A lot of great technical work in cinematography, costume and production design, make it a beautiful film to watch and enjoy.But, there are some problems. The casting is very uneven with some almost amateur acting in smaller roles. The music is heavy handed, underlining and cueing every emotion. The script seems very simple A to B to C with everything overly convenient in the plot. Nick Hornby is an excellent writer, so the adaptation of his novel may have simplified the book to the point of obvious progression. Whoever did the casting may have had political pressure because some of the actors are just bad, even though they look perfect, thanks to accurate hair, makeup & costuming.Ronan is assured a Best Actress nomination for her subtle and interesting work, which keeps you engaged the whole way. As a whole, the film is more entertaining than "Carol," which is set one year later in 1953, but feels hermetically sealed with overly careful tiptoeing around the lesbian romance. "Brooklyn" is also carefully made with getting the period details right, but feels much more alive and rousing than the somber "Carol." The lead actor, Emory Cohen, seems to have studied The Bowery Boys and doesn't seem authentic Italian Brooklyn, but his scenes with Ronan make you want the romance to win.From the overwhelming positive reviews (98% on RT), was expecting a better, not such mixed bag.

I would watch Saoirse Ronan in just about anything, and she proves once again that she has true range and star quality.I was reluctant to see this movie previously because I had the impression that it would be depressing. However, without revealing any spoilers, I can say that it is in fact an uplifting and emotionally engaging story that many viewers would enjoy.The comic relief scenes also contribute balance and lightness, with charming appearances by Julie Walters and Jim Broadbent.

I'm not as impressed with Brooklyn as I had hoped to be. Despite the talented actors involved, the fact that the title of the film removes any doubt as to the outcome and the less than exceptional writing and directing leaves me indifferent. There is little to no character development for anyone involved in the story other than the lead and it seems as if the vast majority of the film is purely background and lead up to a conflict which is over almost before it began. Brooklyn is okay to watch on a lazy day when one has nothing else to do but there are several better options available at the theatre at this time.

Trite, dull, poorly written and endless. Poor Irish girl leaves Ireland to seek her fortune, gets seaskick, gets department store job, meets Italian plumber, returns to Ireland for family emergency, tempted to stay but returns to Brooklyn. Art direction is great, costumes are dreadful, makeup is awful.
it felt like every other coming of age movie I'd seen, but a nice sort of twist as the story came to a conclusion

Beautiful production design and impeccable acting in this period piece that lacks an active protagonist. A couple of plot holes are patched up with heartstrings, but they're still gaping. Worth a watch, but don't expect too much meat on the bone.
Yes, this movie is just as boring as its poster suggests.
This film does a good job of portraying someone split between two places. CDW

This is frustrating, because the first two thirds of this film is actually quite good. A fairly touching, genuinely funny at times story of a young girl finding her own place in the world. Then she goes back to Ireland after a death in her family, and the movie lost me HARD by turning into a liar-revealed story and in doing so I lost any sympathy I had for the lead character. All that she had to say was ONE THING to ANY ONE of her friends and none of what follows happens. It honestly made me think she's a rather horrible person, either for even considering staying and abandoning what she had in Brooklyn, or for continuing to let people believe staying and all that implies was even possible. Yet through the framing I'm supposed to feel sympathetic to her? No, I don't: the old shopkeeper may be a miserable person, but I'm sorry she's in the right here. Ugh. Still, I cannot deny the first two thirds is actually very good, the cinematography is excellent, and the acting is good all around (although personally I think Ronan has gorgeous eyes but is a bit stiff at times - she needed to be more natural). As such, I don't hate this like I did "Boyhood" as its not boring like that was, but oh boy did this ever drop the ball with me.

An Oscar-bait movie and one that your grandmother will surely eat up, I nevertheless connected with these characters and found it a beautiful depiction of the classical conflict of leaving home and finding your place in the world. Not a must-see film but works well within the predictable and conventional genre of period melodrama.
Saoirse Ronan's personal fashion show with beautiful graphics. A typical BBC pipeline product.

I've never been to Boston, but I've always thought it a c**t of a city. Not just because of its sickening support of the terrorist murderers of the IRA, or its overly-sentimental dewy-eyed oirish heritage, but because its fans and adherents always seemed the sort of people who are long on arrogance and short on morality, and this film kind of sets the record straight. As one who was at a school loosely linked to similar scandals in the UK, it is important that a decent account is made of these disgusting clerics and their corrupt church. Spotlight is well-meaning and although almost marred by Ruffalo's insufferable scene-chewing performance, makes a decent fist of telling the story but with notable omissions in that we see few survivors and - apart from one jaw-dropping all-to-brief scene - no abusers. But although it rattles along, it doesn't climax and there's nothing here that comes close to All The President's Men, the benchmark by which such a movie has to be set.
what happened after will make a better movie

Two stars solely for the subject matter of which I approve thoroughly - McCarthy's tone boils down to "if everyone in the Newsroom talks quickly it'll seem like things are more important" - I could tell an actor directed this. There was no conflict in the Newsroom everyone just agreed with each other which missed a trick I think - and mark ruffallo's performance was highly distracting he wasn't warm or engaging and I felt the other actors had to act around rather than with him, he seemed so engrossed in his character acting he couldn't truly interact with the others, who, by the way, all did a great job. I didn't like the way this film handled itself at all - it was like a bad TV show. McCarthy and Ruffallo ruined this for me, and as the director and an actor with the most screentime this was bad, everyone else did the best they could. I'm not giving this extra points just because of the subject matter which every other critic seems to want to do.

I was raised very Catholic and no longer practice and do not consider myself such. I honestly do not see what everyone is raving about with this movie. I almost fell asleep during the first 30 minutes it is very slow moving! The only reason I gave it 2 stars is because of the acting talent. Some of the limes are so badly written it's almost laughable. There is no chemistry between the actors. The cast is seriously lacking in diversity. This story has been told too many times and I was hoping that possibly the movie would add a different perspective to it. Instead it just beat the same add dead horse we have heard for years. Same old stuff just repackaged. I have no idea how this movie got a nomination for best directing when the majority of it takes place in one room!

Good but overrated. This was no "All The President"s Men." Simply not crackling and gripping as expected. All performances were excellent, led by Keaton, but Oscar worthy is debatable. All the unknown actors and bit roles very much out-shined the bigger performances. Oscar nod for Rachel McAdams for mostly taking notes on a pad is perplexing to say the least. Overall did not live up to the hype based on nominations. Direction was excellent and worthy of nod but could not create the tension it needed. It was easy to lose track of all the names and characters that are mentioned in rapid-fire fashion throughout. Most dissapointing was Liev Schreiber in a very under developed role.
Don't care for pedophiles or covering it up, but just too sad and preachy. Mark Ruffalo couldn't show an emotional range if you punched him in the balls during a blow job.

I guess each individual does have different tastes in movies. I just saw this one, it was pretty good, i can see why it's rated very high. It was well written, well directed, great acting, i actually was very impressed with Ruffalo's performance. I think if i was more into these kind of movies, i would of adore more, but still good movie.
A great story...told poorly....

"Spotlight" Cast a Shadow on the Catholic ChurchWith an all-star cast and a compelling story, "Spotlight" delivers a blandly straightforward telling of the priest sex-abuse scandal and cover-up through the investigative story featured in the Boston Globe in the early 2000s. The city of Boston was torn apart by the scandal that had lasted for decades, and according the film, many people worked to shield the Church from the consequences of the scandal. Without the cover-up, the scandal would not have lasted so long. However well done and easy to follow the story was, it was predictable. Few revelations were made for me. Certainly, it is an important story to tell, and I am glad I saw the film. However, none of the characters lived up to the power of story itself and the actors adding little to its telling. This may be the case of too much story, too little screen time. The film attempted in a couple of cases to make the suffering of the survivors real, but it played like an episode of "Law and Order: Special Victims Unit" and not like a feature film. It was too small for such a lofty topic. In the film, they often mentioned that people died, but it seemed unreal. Examples of that were need to bring it home. The film covered too much time without making the connections for the audience. I really want to like this film more, but it fails as cinema in too many ways. It would have made a better Lifetime Channel Drama as it was written. ??Rating: Matinee"Spotlight" is good but not great. After a while, Mark Ruffalo's (playing lead reporter Mike Rezendez) pained expression wears thin. Does he have any other look? Not much in this film. Stanley Tucci puts in a good turn as a lawyer working with the survivors, but the rest of the cast is pedestrian. Perhaps it was the writing, but the film and characters didn't greatly impact me despite the best intentions of the filmmakers and the tragedy of the true story. Peace,Tex Shelters

What a boring boring, boring, boring movie. Quick synopsis and I'll save ya 7.50 and 2 hours.Scene 1: Overpaid actors sit in office talking about 13 potential pedophiles1 Hr Later...Scene 2: There's 40 pedophiles.2 Hours Later....Scene 3: They're all pedophiles. Fin.
"The Best of the Year", huh, for real??!!!I found 21 years ago was way much better.

certainly entertaining enough. a good story. but i realy didnt have any emotional investment in the film. i understand that it had to focus on the investigation. that it was an ode to investigative journalism... that the story was really to big and it had to focus on the journalists and not and part of the story that could have easily been emotional. or could have had more of an emotional story arc. none of the performances were that great as none of them really had too much to do. noe one has anything challenging. liev schreiber was the only one of note. i though mark ruffalo had a couple very odd moments. its a whats for dinner movie.
A solid enough movie, well done, but definitely over hyped.
Overrated for an old news...

The true story behind the film dwarfs it both in the moment and after - when its greatest impact is felt through a series of pointed, factual inserts about what the team's work ultimately laid bare. Ruffalo does memorable, if mannered, work, and the film is brisk and intellectually engaging. It's not, as some purport, a stellar achievement in film; but, rather, a serviceable, workmanlike documenting of a stellar achievement in journalism.
This movie was not that great. It gets a high rating based on the content. All these priests getting in trouble....but movie wise....not that great.

Spotlight was a good movie. Not great, not memorable, but it kept my attention. It also reminded me of a movie released in 1975, Three Days of the Condor, which in spite of it's one similarity to this movie, was indeed Great. What did they have in common? In both cases they promulgated a big lie, by sanctifying the New York Times (or in this case, it's subsidiary, Boston Glob) and it's 'journalists' as constituting the last line of defense of our civil-liberties in this country. What it clearly demonstrated: if someone happens to be on the list of people that Liberals and Leftists despise, these so-called journalists will leave no stone unturned in their attempt to discredit, defame and if possible destroy that person professionally and personally. However, if you happen to be on their list of people who can do no wrong -- they will do whatever is necessary to prop up whatever lies, half-truths, or popular prejudices they can to prevent an inconvenient truth about that person from seeing the light of day. So, for those who prefer to think of this movie as pure fiction, taking place on a planet nowhere near our solar-system, I gave it 3-starts. !;)
What there is of the story is good but having lived through it...only half the story

It's very issue focused, rather than character focused-an aspect that makes it hard for me to get involved. It often gets overly sappy, focused on these victims to get emotion out of you. I did like Mark Ruffalo. He was great. Rachel McAdams and Keaton were pretty good too.
Tightly written, well acted and details a very important story. But lacks suspense and character depth.
The movie you can take your mom and dad to this awards season.

Did you know the Catholic Church has been complicit in thousands of sexual abuse scandals? If somehow that's news to you, then the movie might be riveting, but I can't help but feel the drama is supposed to come from the revelation of information that's been common knowledge for over a decade. I feel like a dunce any time a movie seems to get unanimous rave reviews while I remain unaffected, but I'm just not sure how this was supposed to be interesting. Despite what almost everyone says, the acting is not electrifying; it is, like everything else in this movie, simply competent and functional. (Rachel McAdams's delivery seems particularly forced.) The standout, however, is Liev Schreiber, who paradoxically generates the most interest and charisma through a character who essentially has no personality.But where was the drama in this movie? The Spotlight team makes a lot of phone calls, conducts a lot of interviews, and looks over a lot of documents. That's the movie. There's no arc. As it unspools, you find that the sexual abuse scandal is massive and involves more and more people, but again, we already knew that. There isn't any story telling to speak of, just procedural what-have-you to reach a foregone conclusion.So if your idea of a taught thriller consists of characters talking to other characters whose identity and/or importance isn't really described; or if you like seeing people read documents, the contents and importance of which aren't fully explained; or if you're in the mood to see characters tackle a big problem that honestly doesn't really affect their welfare and puts very little at stake...then for you, this may be Best Picture 2016.

Story wise this is a great film and it leaves the audience completely overwhelmed by the extent of the abuse and cover-up.That being said, would it have killed the director and the producer to add some passion to the acting and some type of musical overture? The cheap and obvious attempts during the actual movie to be classified as a "thriller" were just flat out crap!
This movie is utterly ridiculous. To blame an entire religion, instead of indivual people for their actions is just another attempt from the far left to demonize religion. ZERO STARS.

there was nothing really that worked for me in this one- director, screenwriter, editor, cinematographer- everything just felt forced and awkward and just brought the whole tone into more uncomfortable technical areas then anything the movie spoke about.

The pedophile priest scandal was very bad. And sadly, so is this movie. Most critics love it. They're wrong. It was billed as a "thriller". It's not. No suspense at all. It views more like a cartoon take-down of the evil Catholic Church (insert cheers here). And the acting is solid wood: The big shot at high emotion is the "It's Time!" (to destroy Cardinal Law) speech by Ruffalo's character, and, as Oscar Wilde might have put it, you'd have to have a heart of stone not to laugh at the overwrought dramatics. And some niggling questions remain: Has there ever been an infantile priest like the one in this movie who confesses his crime to Rachel McAdam - on the doorstep in mere seconds! Is Rachel's character guilty of elder abuse when she shows her dear old grannie, a three-times-a-week church-goer, the shocking news about the scandal in her church? That little silent scene must be the most ludicrous polemical overkill in the history of movies. And why is Michael Keaton's character surprised that so many people call in claiming clerical abuse after the big story breaks? Isn't he supposed to be a hard-nosed journo?Oh, Oscar, Oscar! Sort it all out for us, please.

Preachy (no pun intended), forced, self-righteous, and yet another movie that demonizes religion. I'm not all that religious, and yet even I'm getting sick of this denigrating, Hollywood trend.There is some good acting to be had here, though. Michael Keaton, in particular, is enjoying a deserved renaissance. For the life of me, however, I do not understand the appeal of Mark Ruffalo. Besides just being generally annoying, I just don't find him to be a convincing actor.

It's slow but its horrors is tense and nerve-racking at times. It Follows may have an eerily-horrifying concept but its dull dialogue and plain narrative defeats the clever scare-tactics the film offers and makes for a less-than-memorable frightening flick. 3/5

A teenage woman has sex with her boyfriend and then discovers that a shape-shifting demon follows her; if it catches up, she dies.Here is what this film is trying to do: it's trying to send up the horror movie formula of if a female character has sex, she's sure to die. It's trying to be an homage to (or satire of) John Carpenter's original Halloween film.Here is what the film actually accomplishes: it annoys the living shit out of me. The follow shots and heavy-handed music do nothing to add suspense. Rather, they're almost comic in their over-drawn melodrama. And let's talk a while about this demon. What about hand stuff? Does the demon only get transferred with procreative sex? What if she doesn't come? What about lesbian sex? And why is the demon sometimes one shape but other times another? Why is it only occasionally naked? Why did the demon kill everyone else, but when it catches up to our heroine, it only plays with her hair? Why does it have so much trouble with doorknobs but is capable of flying or climbing on a roof, standing there with Osama bin Laden's beard over its dick? I know the film doesn't want to answer these questions, but they're so obvious.Overall, what's being hailed as "one of the greatest American horror films in years" is a dumb piece of shit.

Incredibly disturbing, It Follows is a creepy and atmospheric low-budget indie horror film. An allegory about STDs (in part), the story follows a young girl who, after having sex with her boyfriend, is stalked by a mysterious shapeshifting creature that can only be seen by those who've had sex with an infected person, and it can only be escaped from (for a time) by passing on the infection to another person through sex. Maika Monroe gives a strong performance that's nuanced and really shows her struggle to come to grips with her situation. However, the director makes some odd choices in creating a setting, as it comes off as a strange alternative reality with a mixture of futuristic and retro fashions and technologies (which is quite distracting). Additionally, the creature effects are rather grotesque; with the creature often appearing mangled and in various stages of nudity. A problematic film, It Follows delivers some effective scares, but the who and the what are so vague that the story ends up being rather unsatisfying.
Smart and original (but still imperfect) horror with a killer soundtrack to match.

THE RING GETS CHLAMYDIA - My Review of IT FOLLOWS (3 Stars)Often pretentious, overly metaphorical, and uneven in pace, IT FOLLOWS is still writer/director David Robert Mitchell's praiseworthy attempt to inject a little originality into the often stale horror genre. Whereas THE RING was built on the premise that a mysterious videotape would bring death to its viewers, IT FOLLOWS promises being haunted by a shape-shifting specter unless you have sex with someone to transfer the target over to them. Think of it as the consequences of acquiring a sexually transmitted infection, but with more horrific symptoms. As allegories go, it's rich with potential, and Mitchell clearly strives to make the most out of it. He works hard with cinematographer Mike Gioulakis to achieve an endlessly fluid shooting style rife with striking, unusual framing. One unfortgettable shot of blood in a swimming pool is almost worth the price of admission alone. Add a heavy 80s-style synth score, a strange, timeless, quasi-70s/80s production design that mixes cell phones with rabbit ear televisions, old rusty cars, a zonked-out, naturalistic acting style exhibited by its young cast, and the strangest clamshell cameo Kindle device that has never existed, and you're entering John Carpenter Land by way of Terrence Malick. The Malick reference gets its due in not only the unforced, elliptical way our characters converse but in choices Mitchell makes, such as concentrating on a shot of our heroine's hand grazing grass and flowers during a particularly quiet moment right before something awful occurs.The film opens strong, with a twirling 360 degree shot of a young girl racing out of her home dressed in bra, panties and high heels. She's being chased by something unseen and before you know it, she meets an unexpectedly grisly fate. From here, we meet our heroine, Jay (Maika Monroe), who looks like the the product of a fourgy between Kelly Clarkson, Kat Dennings, Reese Witherspoon and Chloe Sevigny, as she wades in her backyard, above ground pool. This is one laid back teen. She's so laconic, she can't even be bothered to shoo an ant crawling across her arm. It's suburban Detroit and Jay's life consists of being observed by her horny pre-teen neighbors, drinking with her friends and family, and dating an easygoing guy. It's at this date where things go seriously and irrevocably wrong. I won't spoil the plot much further, but the aftermath of some backseat sex isn't anywhere close to what Jay imagined. In most horror films, you pay for having sex. Here, sex is the only way out. IT FOLLOWS really turns up the creep factor after this initial sexual encounter, with a shocking cut to the next scene. It seems to be Mitchell's terror equivalent to finding out your partner just intentionally infected you with an STI. With Jay dumped back home looking like a rape victim, those closest to her rally by her side to help her escape her fate. In an almost silent performance, Monroe must convey fear and a certain guilt for the rest of the film. There are a few good scares of the "jump out of your seat when somebody goes 'Boo!' variety" and a few haunting scenes where she's being stalked. The framing of the shots truly helps these sequences flourish as you're made to look around constantly to discover the predator. Knowing the threat could be coming from anywhere is part of this movie's simmering tension. Additionally, like a diagnosis of syphilis, our main character has a tough time disclosing what's happening to her. Unfortunately, there's not much else to the film. Our leads run and run and run, stopping sometimes to have sex until they come up with a plan to conquer this "thing". Although visually stunning, that big sequence doesn't make a lot of sense, and it feels like the rules changed slightly to justify what happens. Ultimately, it feels like the film is a little light on incident and lacks a satisfying resolution, ending up feeling like a light campfire story instead of a big, hearty meal. More haunting than scary and more metaphor than fleshed-out storytelling, IT FOLLOWS is an admiral homage. Rich Vreeland's score is an acquired taste. It booms in almost every frame in a way that reminded me of Christopher Nolan's DARK KNIGHT and is highly evocative of the score from HALLOWEEN. It feels intentional and will either feel like a propulsive addition to the storytelling (my feeling) or annoy the hell out of you. Same goes with the odd, can't-place-it time in which the story is set.
