For me, it kept me engaged in the film, with its vague, hazy memories of a time where we would have to talk with each other instead of texting. Others will find it to be a pretentious conceit. Fair enough, but love it or hate it, IT FOLLOWS has a lot on its mind and Mitchell clearly wants to establish a new, methodical voice in film storytelling.

I am not sure what all the hype was about for this horror movie. The critics on Rotten Tomato gave it 96% fresh and 66% of the audience liked it. I am definitely more in line with the audience. Spoilers AheadI kept hearing that it was so intense, and that you'd be scanning everyone in the background to see who is after the victim. Um, no. It was completely obvious who was after the intended victim. Most of the time the scene was so bare of other people, there was no other choice as to who it would be. The main character's acting just checked out after she told her friends that something was following her, and when they finally believed her. Jay looked comatose, constantly lying against her friend, or even just straight up sleeping. I would think she would be way more hyped up, on constant alert, and afraid of going to sleep. More like a Nightmare on Elm Street vibe.You needed to have sex to pass it onto the next person, so the creature would be after them instead of you. What if she were to have sex with three different guys at the same time? (Yes, one in each opening.) Would it pass on to all three of them? It might make me a slut, but I would try it, just on the off chance it worked. The creature having to kill three people before it got back to me is way better odds than just one person.And the end scene in the pool where the creature is throwing electrical items at Jay. Okay, I suppose I can go with each item coming unplugged from an electrical source before it hit the water. But some of them were on really long extension cords. Every single one the creature threw was on a short cord??The other thing with the pool, they are in the most run down part of Detroit and every building near by is super run down or vacant/vandalized. But here you have this gorgeous brick building in perfect condition. Even better it has running electricity and a huge, well maintained swimming pool. No. Just No.And what was up with Jay's friends (Annie?) giving a monologue about not being able to go past Eight Mile when she was a kid because that's where the suburbs ended and the bad part of town began. Since the writer is from Michigan, this was his nod to his home state, but it served no purpose to the plot, and in fact just stood out as super odd.This is such a minor thing, but Jay's cast. The first time she's just walking around her pool with the cast on. That's super fun. At least be on a raft floating around. And then later on she's in actual bodies of water. Even if it's a fiberglass one, you are not to get it wet. I know a stupid, picky thing, but just one more thing to add to the list of annoyances.And where the hell were all the parents in this movie. I know it's a typical horror movie, and the parents need to be elsewhere for the teens to get into trouble. But every other adult was home. A woman unpacking her groceries, lots of people doing yard work, etc.What I took away from this is if you are a teen/young adult, do not have sex. You will get an STD, maybe even a supernatural one.There were a couple good parts; the musical score did it's job by keeping me off balance a bit, and it did provide some tension. I also enjoyed the cinematography having a more 80's slasher movie vibe to it. But at points where the camera is scanning the scene 360 degrees looking for the creature, I had to close my eyes because it was making me queasy. But that may have been the objective, if so, well done.Although it may not seem like it, I really do feel bad not having liked it. I was so excited to find a good horror movie, since they are rare lately. But alas, No. Just No.
This movie was neither fresh nor scary. I don't understand how it even has such a high rating ( $$$?)

Dumb, derivative and above all, awful.How this film can be considered in such high regard is probably the most menacing thing about it. When you consider that this scores higher than Hitchcock's legendary "Psycho" or Carpenters masterful "Halloween", you will be deeply disturbed.The plot is riddled with holes and is no more complex than a Tom and Jerry cartoon and it's multiple levels are presumably that it is a metaphor for STD's.If however, you live in fear of an easily avoidable adversary throwing a toaster at you then prepare to be horrified.Don�t waste your time, watch a classic horror film instead.

Either I'm a terrible viewer, or these top critics are out of their minds. How great is a movie with shitty eerie sound effect and terribly slow plot? The first quarter was nice and attractive, but then it just turned into a disaster. The only highlight I remembered is the use of panorama.

How this movie gets 97 is beyond me. How so many people think this movie is good is even more puzzling. What is good about it? In my opinion it looked like a sub par student film. Please explain to me why 90% of the camera shots had to be a zoom, pan, tilt, dolly/tracking shot? Is it because the movie is called "It Follow" so the camera has to 'follow' all the characters? If so, that may sound clever, but it just seemed well overdone, plus it made the movie's pacing even slower than it already was. And thats another thing...slowest...movie...ever!So what are the rules? We know Freddy can only get you in your sleep, Jason cant do water, dont watch the tape and The Ring girl can't get you, etc. What are the rules of "It" other than banging someone else to pass it off to them? We don't know. And that, for lack of a better word, is stupid.But how do we even know that rule? Hugh tells Jay. But how did he find out? He said he didnt remember the girl he got it from, so who told him? If I'm just sitting there minding my business and notice someone walking towards me REALLY, REALLY SLOWLY, I may think its weird, I may think its creepy, I may even run away. But under no circumstances will it just pop into my head that this person is following cuz i just screwed that chick. And even further from my consideration would be sleeping with someone else so that it starts following her and not me.And what the hell year is it supposed to be? Old ass tvs, old ass phone, but cell phones (girl in the beginning), and that weird makeup ereader thing seemed like something relatively current. I'll give it to them that its somewhat original, but it made no sense at all. The kids never have an actual plan of attack. Why not just go to Japan or something. The thing is so damn slow that by the time it walked there you'd be like 90 and wouldnt give a shit anymore.I was honestly expecting this movie to score in the 30s, maybe...MAYBE in the 40s. But 97! WHY?!

There is nothing overtly bad about this movie, but neither is there anything that impressive that will stand out. The film is marked as horror, but really it seems to have as much comedy as horror to me - in other words, this isn't about to be the start of a franchise such as a Nightmare on Elm Street, Friday the 13th, Candyman, or numerous other horror flicks. It's more horror to the main character and a couple of her friends. The audience? Not so much. To be blunt, I personally considered this as much comedy as horror, and for the "critics consensus" about it being terrifying? Hardly. Worth seeing as a rental, but really not that frightening.
I would give this less that half a star I could. 90 minutes of pure midi file hell. 2 million dollar budget, it shows. Awful, upon awful.
It is just horrible, in the bad way. I can't believe someone enjoied this. It is just awful.

This film was ridiculous. Seeing the 97% on Rotten tomatoes I figured it must be good. But I was horribly mistaken.The concept seems parodical, but takes itself completely serious. The characters are unlikable and the pacing is atrocious.I did get a good laugh near the end, but passed that it was just bad. It wasn't scary, it wasn't suspenseful. The attempts at suspense just came across as slow and boring. Just. Bad.

didn't particularly like it or hate it. whatever the filmmakers were trying to do here, it could have been done a lot scarier and with more interesting characters. outstanding cinematography and soundtrack.

The acting was terrible, it hopped from scene to scene without explanation, and the ending left you glad it was finally over. It was not scary in the slightest and and most of the movie made no sense at all. It wasn't worth the dollar and change it cost to rent it from a Redbox.
it sucks. i have no idea why this is getting good reviews.

Uggggh. This movie made no sense. It started well, with decent, dimensional characters -- but then it started breaking its own rules, had characters fail to act even basic questions about what they were facing, and then just abruptly ended with no Act 3 at all. WTF? The only thing scary about it was seeing the urban decay of Detroit, which looked straight out of Fallout 4. FAIL.
If u want 100 minutes of panic attack and a lot of slut shaming this movie is for u

It Follows is heavily flawed in its story. Although the technical execution is superb, what one needs in order to make a good film is a satisfying story, an ultimate climax, something that the tension builds up to. What we get in It Follows is all of the suspense without the payoff. This review is coming from a mindset that loves metaphors, and is constantly looking for them when watching film. Because of this reason, the film confused the hell outta me, for it had no distinct purpose. I couldn't tell what the director was trying to SAY. Unlike other modern, critically acclaimed horror films (The Babadook comes to mind), It Follows doesn't know what it's symbolism is actually attempting to convey, and for this reason, the film gets muddled down into a pretty cheesy horror flick that probably doesn't deserve the acclaim that it has received. A disappointing, frustrating watch.

Probably the most overrated movie i've ever seen. I first saw this movie before I read any of the reviews on rotten tomatoes or IMBD and I thought it was awful. It does not leave you in suspense or scare you throughout. The only scares, if you want to call them that, were jump scares, only one of which not being predictable. It definitely is not smart, as it is literally about an STD. The acting is mediocre along with the plot which overall makes the movie extremely boring. At points in the movie I felt myself falling asleep. Overall a boring movie with mediocre acting, a bad plot, and extremely predictable and stupid jumpscares.
Absolutely horrible movie. I don't get what people see in this. Is it original? A little but it's stupid. Terrifying? No way. Smart? Really?! You can't be serious. What a joke!
Dull dialogue, little suspense, not particularly scary. This is a horror film? Maybe I've just grown out of the genre. It just seemed sort of silly.

I feel like I'm taking crazy pills after watching this and seeing all the rave reviews. This was the biggest piece of shit horror film that makes no sense and is not scary at all. Moral of the film..having sex is bad, mk? Seriously? Wtf. Cool music though I like that odd 5/8 time signature in the main theme I played some pretty sick air drums during one part.
One of the worst horror movies. Story makes little sense.

A post-modern Halloween wannabe that is actually a "horror" movie for those you don't like horror movies.Avoid this pretentious film.

Overall, it reminded me too much of Final Destination. Would monogamy solve the problem? Just pass the curse back and forth every couple of days to keep the stalker at bay. Or set up a sex ring spread across the globe to keep it walking in circles. I liked the music and the overall look/feel. But, it just left me shrugging afterwards.
This move is appallingly bad. The entity is not scary and the characters are frustrating. It failed on every level of a horror film - it was not scary AT ALL!!!!!!!!!!!

Mood does not a movie make, but that seems to be much of what this overrated exercise in alleged horror seems to rely on to carry the film. Its heavy-handed STD symbolism and allusions to classic horror films don't add much either, especially when weighted down by an excess of prolonged shots of characters emoting while contemplating their fates. I missed seeing this in theaters when it was initially released (I was attending the Chicago Film Festival at the time), but I'm glad I didn't waste any effort trying to fit this one in during its initial run. Easily one of the year's most overhyped offerings.
Slow paced, but at the end (and more importantly) really unsettling and terrifying

The premise of this horror movie is pretty good - but it does make the monster strangely similar to a venereal disease. It follows you around until you pass it to someone else by having sex with them. Fortunately, it walks very slow - which is creepy and creates a great deal of suspense. The monster also takes different guises, so a different actor plays it each time. So, a bunch of teens confront this threat but it is a real challenge to stop; plaudits to the movie for keeping things realistic and practical (taking its cues from night of the living dead) even as the whole concept is not. The soundtrack and the burnt out neighbourhoods of Detroit add to the spooky atmosphere (and the absence of gore is a plus for me). Unfortunately, the filmmakers seem to run out of steam with their premise and can't quite produce a satisfying ending. But this is still one of the better recent horror flicks, in a genre that is pretty tough to get right.

Even if I had not heard of flattery reviews It Follows received, I would have found it not entertaining. Premise is very strong and interesting but to keep it realistic and teen friendly, there is nothing happening on screen except for nudity. I would call cinematography weak as well as there was not much shaking of camera which was eminent for this genre. Another aspect is adult absence in the movie which is confusing.Not so entertaining movie which completely failed to build strong work on good idea.

This movie is not a waste of life don't get me wrong, its a solid 2,5 stars maybe even 3. Without a doubt the movie is scary and has a unique way of delivering its horror. However the script is sparse, dotted with awkward moments where another line or two could have helped nurture the scene a bit more. Perhaps the writer/director David Mitchel thought to fill these gaps with some kind of visual narration but it rang empty (fell on blind eyes?) in my opinion.Putting some awkward moments aside, in general the film is shot well and the sound design, excellent! If you enjoyed Final Destination (the original) then you may find the the kind of suspense beats on offer here familiar and I would recommend this movie in kind.

This movie was lame. I don't know how it got such a high score.... "it" is just a weird killer thing that gets passed by banging, but it doesn't....uninteresting concept. It did not leave me "lingering" it left me with a weird face and wanting to write this negative review. Don't waste your time, the movie Teeth was better and that movie blows too.
Such an annoying soundtrack; reminds me of Turkish psychedelic '80s movies. The movie itself was't that bad. I really liked some parts, quite scary at times. Acting was okay for a bunch of teenagers.

55%Saw this on 13/8/15Aside from a few jump scares and a reasonably good performance from Maika Monroe, It follows is an unoriginal film with a pedestrian story that still thinks that those who loose their virginity before marriage are to be put under the knife. These are the kind of shits that the original Scream(1996) so effectively mocked. This is also a kind of film that you feel like appreciating while you watchit, but once it's over, you end up feeling how unmemorable all the shit really is.
I tried to understand it but i simply could not, the effects were messy although the acting and soundtrack was great.

So this movie got crazy good reviews when it came out which got me interested in seeing it. I know I am in the minority but I did not like it. It just becomes so inconsistent and leaves so much stuff open ended that is just became frustrating. There are these scenes that happen and are never answered, the kids make the dumbest decisions (especially nearly the end with the whole pool thing) when they know all about "it", the music got super annoying, and I just thought it was not scary at all, in fact it was kind of boring! I liked Maika Monroe she was a good lead here, it was all filmed in Detroit which gave it a good suburban feel, and it was cool that it had a low budget type of feel to it.
I can't even give this movie 1/2 of a star. This was a ridiculously stupid movie. I've never watched a movie with so many rave reviews only to be dumbfounded at how bad it was.

Oh, farting chick. Charming. I hate the farting narcoleptic girl. Do these kids have parents? It gets major points for featuring a Father and Son commercial. Some of the night scenes in Detroit in slow mo with jarring music are quite effective. The ending made no sense. Why would there be a bloody pool if it was already sot before? Cause it's in water, that was never electrocuted? This cause a half-star deduction. But the amazing Detroit-ness adds that half star.Paul: "You could...pass it on."Subtle.

It follows has a pretty unique story line where our lead actress, Jay, contacts an STD (Sexual Transmitted Demon) from a seemingly innocent sexual encounter. She soon finds out that this innocent encounter will eventually haunt her until she finds somebody else to pass the (STD) to. I feel like this movie had a lot of potential, but lacked a lot of depth. The story seemed to be one big loop hole. Good graphics, great soundtrack, alright actors. Like I said, it had potential, but over all I think it was just alright, and the story didn't make much sense.

Very cheesy all and all.

It Follows is the kind of movie that you bring up at parties when you want to pretend you have taste. "Oh, you went to see the latest Saw? No, I'm not really into mainstream horror. Have you seen It Follows? It's more of a cerebral horror film, you know?" The premise sounds like something a fundamentalist church would make up to scare kids into chastity: out on a date, the main character has sex with a boy. Immediately afterward, he reveals that he's passed on the mother of all STDs: a shapeshifting monster that will slowly but constantly track her down and kill her. The only way she can escape is by sleeping with someone else and passing it down the line.Shot with an eye for unflattering lighting that would make Terry Richardson proud, and scored with minimal electronic music reminiscent of Drive, It Follows is certainly stylish. Every location in the movie could double as an American Apparel photoshoot. The story drifts from abandoned factory ruin-porn to an instagrammable cabin to a normcore chic suburban living room. The characters, rock a "bland as cool" aesthetic that instantly made me feel old. Our protagonist (the one being followed by the "It") and her friends sleepwalk through an adult-shaped world where the adults seem mostly absent. Even as an unspeakable horror walks inexorably toward them, they behave like teenagers: pouting and procrastinating, lusting and bloviating. And always, over everything,they project that melodramatic sense of doom every angsty teen has felt. Though unlike most teens, in this case it's completely justified. Over the course of the movie, with the help of her friends and the boy next door, the girl attempts to escape through various means. What originally looked like a metaphor about the dangers of unprotected sex proves to be a larger exploration of the transition to adulthood and how the discovery of sex and our own mortality are linked. The running and screaming seems, somehow, more existential than usual. The fear seems more grounded in reality, despite the monster. The requisite sex scenes are less about lust than the loss of innocence and the transience of relationships. Far from turning the characters into sex objects, (there's no actual nudity by the way) they remind the viewer just how young and vulnerable these kids are. Overall, this is horror for those who like their chills flavored with a little intellectual pretension, a popcorn movie for those who insist that would rather critique than cry out in surprise. If you're looking to be titillated with blood and boobs you're going to be disappointed. But if you're a college sophomore who needs to bang out a five page paper for your intro to film class, It Follows is a great choice. It's neither as terrifying nor as deep as it would like to pretend, but there's enough in there to earn you an A.
Was very slow, boring and kept no interest.

It showcased performers playing their actual ages while talking and dressing the ages they represented which was a nice change for film makers though the director was in love with our main character's feet a little too much. This movie had potential to be better, but suffered from long bouts of nothing more than character development which it did indeed succeed in making the characters realistic and likable. Hmmm where do I start with this one? I don't hate it like some people do. But I don't actually love it like others. For me, it fell in the middle. It was another great first half, marred by a dull second half.First, let me go over the good. The soundtrack is amazingly awesome. It may have the best horror score in decades. It's reminiscent of old John Carpenter. Speaking of Carpenter, this movie is so heavily inspired by his movies that it almost comes off as a shameless ripoff. It Follows is basically the best Michael Myers movie that doesn't actually have Michael Myers. The way things are shot and characters interact is very reminiscent of Halloween. Like I said before, the first half of this movie is great. It's full of wonderfully creepy ideas and the teenagers actually act like teenagers. There's a nice slow, tense build, and the car scene and the dilapidated building scene are well done and creepy.But that's where things started to go bad though. Not so bad the movie sucked, but just underwhelming. The first major issue is the "it" itself. It really should be just one monster with one identity. The whole ambiguous "it can look like anyone" thing just made it less terrifying when you see it on screen. I get that they were probably going for an STD-type metaphor, but I just don't find old ladies, chubby naked girls peeing themselves, and hipsters to be all that frightening. Why not have the "it" be faceless? Maybe make it naked, but with no discernible gender. Just an idea, but that would be creepy and it would give more of an identity to the monster and make it scarier when it appears on screen. Or maybe the idea of "it" being faceless would make the obvious connections to Halloween a little too obvious. Another issue is there is no real way to fight the monster. That would be fine, but since there is no way to kill the monster the characters just stand around and wait till it shows up, run away, and then do it all over again. There needed to be some sort of goal the characters were working towards. How about a Ring-esque plot where they're trying to figure out where the curse started from and how they can solve it? They could go from place to place until they end up in even worse parts of Detroit (the city by the way is one of the best parts of the movie). Maybe they do or don't find the origins of the curse, but at least it would give them something to do.The ending with the pool seemed confusing and pointless. Their plan was to electrocute it? Did they realize how stupid their plan seemed and that throwing toasters in an olympic-sized pool wasn't going to work anyway? They could actually interact with it, even if they couldn't see it, so why not try to trap it? Then the movie just sort of ends abruptly.So while I enjoyed most of the movie, it really suffers for being underwhelming. It's like everything was in place for a true horror classic to stand next to Halloween, Night of the Living Dead, and A Nightmare on Elm Street, but it falls way short of hitting it over the fence. I can't help but imagine how amazing this would have been if it were pretty much the same movie, but with a Michael Myers-like killer and a Ring-like plot to keep it interesting. It Follows just isn't that scary, despite having some of the most terrifying concepts and ideas to come to a horror movie since masked killers and reanimated corpses.

I watched this movie on the recommendation of a couple of sources because I wanted to see some good horror with my friend. Honestly, I have no clue how this movie has such a high score. If I could describe it with one word it would be "boring". There's a difference between a slow burn and just unnecessary padding. Half the dialogue I was left wondering what the point of putting it there was. At one point there was an aside that sounded like it might be a commentary on classism in America? But it's placement was so strange and added nothing. At no point did they make any attempt to figure out this creature's limitations. Will uninterrupted water - lake, sea, ocean? - with no crossing hinder it? The pool scene implies it can swim, but can it swim across an ocean? For that matter, how fast does it walk? And it's obviously capable of more cognitively involved processes than walking- it throws rocks through windows and apparently recognizes a trap to electrocute it - what's stopping it from walking on transportation exactly? Other than it ruining this movie's "gimmick" of course. I'm not really sure what's so apparently original about this thing. It falls into some pretty common horror movie cliches - from sex inviting in corruption/evil/whathaveyou, to the casual use of women's naked bodies for shock, to the head-desk worthy amount of plot-induced idiocy required of the protagonists to make this setup work. I could've watched 3 Headed Shark Attack instead. At least that movie I know is SUPPOSED to be bad.

Inexplicably earning a 96% on Rotten Tomatoes, "It Follows" benefits from reviewers anticipating that horror movies tend to be utter pieces of crap. Anything that exceeds these expectations gets a positive review. "It Follows" begins with a nice enough premise, practically guaranteed to build white-knuckle tension: promiscuous teens acquire an STD, "se*ually transmitted demon" who stalks them, one at a time, until they're either killed, or they pass the curse onto the next victim. The demon is always making a b-line for the victim, slowly walking. That's pretty scary, right? The only other thing the movie does right is cast a group of average-looking teens and create an environment that feels very real. For a reviewer who has had his fill of whitewashed cinematography, CGI, and perfect skin and teeth, "It Follows" felt refreshingly organic. Unfortunately, that's where the refreshment ends...precisely because that's where the writer/director stopped having anymore ideas. As the creature stalks our heroine hither and yon, the protagonists make no headway on solving the mystery or getting themselves out of the accursed jam. The filmmaker peppers the movie with anachronism, technology out-of-time: black-and-white picture-tube televisions share the same space as a digital e-reader shaped like a makeup compact. When questioned why this was the case, the director said he was trying to confuse the audience and create a "timeless" movie. Hey, idiot! That's not what "timeless" means! Additional groans can be garnered from attempts at poetry and metaphor, and artsy shots that serve no purpose to the story. There's nothing more tedious than posers trying to give their best impression of "meaningful." Stick with the scary formula and make a straightforward horror movie with an ending. "It Follows" might have reinvigorated the genre. As it happens, It Sucks.
Different and spooky at times but I am not convinced it is memorable. I also couldn't help but have this feeling that the film had a message for teens with "loose morals"
The badest review of rottentomatoes

"It Follows" | C- | One of the best premises in horror film history: brilliantly simple and truly terrifying.Unfortunately the writer-director's execution is so poor, the finished product deserves a D (I kept it at "C" level because of the premise and a great lead performance). If you can ignore the embarrassingly bad music/score, check out this overrated mess. Critics have it at 96% but the audience has it at 65%?You'll enjoy the amazing first 30 minutes, then spend the next hour laughing at the filmmakers' horrible decisions (so horrible they're almost entertaining, especially the ridiculous pool scene).
I hate it. Full of stupid melodramatic monologues/conversation that seemed as if they were trying to be very deep but were just very first world teenager problem-y.

If you want an interesting concept executed poorly this is the movie for you. Explanations? Unnecessary. Characters that recognise the great danger they are in? Who needs 'em? Great movie to enjoy if you want to be the most pretentious guy in the room at your Media class end of year film showcase.

The concept of passing on your horror to someone else is somewhat original but money lacks any originality beyond that. "The scariest movie of this generation" as quoted by Michael Roffman of the Consequence of Sound - it is not. I failed to be impressed by fear at any moment of this film.

Idiotic and nonsense with an ending that not only says absolutely nothing about the 90 minutes you waste sitting and expecting something trrifying to happen, but also leaves the gestalt in a comple point of ignorance and helplesness. Someone please tell me why this movie was rated so high ! It was quite boring, and full of cheap thrills. The horror was completely driven by the interfering background score and all the other popular techniques of close up and lack of information for the viewer was explored. There was nothing particularly innovative. It was very average to say the most and painstakingly mindnumbing to say the least. There is a reason why I don't watch Horror. This movie epitomizes it.
Confusing and incoherent.

It Follows may have a pretty terrifying premise - the kind of story that urban legends are born from - but it's much scarier in concept than execution. Personally, this movie that's being hailed as "one of the greatest American horror films in years" is a dumb piece of shit.

Utter crap. Horror is often (rightly) accused of being simply a moral tale, a thinly veiled threat about the dangers of alcohol, sexual curiosity, or disobedience; It Follows makes such a blatant, in-your-face allegory of STDs that it might very well have been a juiced up after-school special. Avoid unless it is free. Even then, be sure you can't think of anything else to do first.

Expectations hit the roof after looking at the reviews, but unfortunately I found it underwhelming as a horror film. Nicely shot with an unusual premise, and some good social commentary aside, doesn't really work as a horror film for me.
sexually transmitted heebie geebies? Its like watching a horror film with Drive theme music in the background And of all places, Eminnem's hometown!

It could have been a really good movie but the plot drags on, characters seem disconnected from story (reality) and just drags on!!!
Not a unique story with some unreasonable events, but a uniquely good looking horror film, beautifully directed. You can enjoy the cinematography & soundtracks.

Listen to me closely, the amount of positive reviews for this brutally terrible movie are both destroying my faith in Rotten Tomatoes and the human race in general. I know you think I might be harsh here, but I am honestly just trying to get you to not waste your life like I did. This movie had terrible acting,a story as empty as my own soul after watching this, and an ending so abrupt and bad that I spent the better part of my evening last night trying to find the person who wrote this, just so I could kick that person in the nuts.Please like better movies in the future and stop hyping up this sort of trash.I gave it half a star on the basis that it succeeded in one aspect of horror, as it is frighteningly bad and as such made me want to vomit myself into oblivion.
I just don't get it. Dull, nothing happens, no charisma from the actors.

This is worth a watch, and maybe I should give it another chance soon, but it's not essential. Music is good and suspense wise it has a couple of decent scares, but it just didn't hold my attention and it had a lack of Giant Sharks.
It was pretty interesting, good movie to see once but not one I'd personally see twice.
The movie was not scary as I expected it to be and since it was the single trick the movie had, it didn't impress me at all.

This horror flick had a lot of potential and it squandered it. The best thing I can say about this movie is its Drive-esque soundtrack, all synthy gloss and New Wave sounds, but even that should tell you something: the soundtrack is kept to a bare minimum for most of the movie.

Still a very worthy effort.

There seems to be quite a few films recently which hearken back to the late 70's/early 80's in terms of filmmaking style. IT FOLLOWS is one of the films in this mold that capture a certain feeling of nostalgia while also having its foot firmly planted in the present. It's about a vague entity that follows you around after having sex with somebody who also has the same problem. Inasmuch as the Friday THE 13TH series was about abstinence, IT FOLLOWS is in a similar vein, with a heavy dose of John Carpenter's HALLOWEEN and Wes Craven for good measure. The most outstanding part of this film is the subtle approach taken with the horror, letting it build quietly without using the score to jolt you. There was also great care taken with the direction and cinematography that helped to build an atmosphere of tension and dread. Even without being a horror movie (albeit, more of a psychological one), the cinematography and camera-work was excellent, with precise, deliberate movement, slow pans and zooms, etc. It was quite artful, to say the least. I should also mention the outstanding score by Disasterpeace, which captures a feeling I haven't felt since watching HALLOWEEN. So, at least on the surface, IT FOLLOWS has a lot going for it. However, I do ask a little bit more from movies I watch than to impress me visually and aurally, and apart from these qualities, IT FOLLOWS was quite banal. The acting was decent, although no one really stood out from the rest. The potential in the setup for this "it" to be anything or anyone allowed for a few good sequences, but it also meant that the narratively was a little too linear for my tastes. It boils down to have sex, wait, and run. And for a 100 minute film, I expected more. There wasn't even an underlying emotional subtext like was in THE BABADOOK. Still, despite being bored through parts of it, the film does manage to pull together for a decent (and appropriate) finish. I would recommend people to see this, but don't go in expecting something revolutionary. There is a little bit of subtext about abstinence/STDs that can be read into IT FOLLOWS and, courtesy of a CHARADE billboard, possibly some meta-commentary on artificiality. However, IT FOLLOWS works perfectly fine as a stylistic exercise that aspires to little more than imitating its cinematic forebears, and does an admittedly good job at it.

Its a good horror to watch if your don't like being frightened with horror movie scare tactics, as they are kept to a minimum. Terror is instead made up for in excellent plot and cinematography. The only let down of this film was the ending, It may have been a little to subtle for me to grasp or it could just been intentionally straight forward, leaving many question unresolved. I've read that there may be a squeal in the works so it may have been sitting itself up for that. Nice too see a more progressive film of this genre. I will be looking out for more work by this team.

So 1-1/2 stars for me on that. If, however, you look at it as an existential film ala Bunuel's The Exterminating Angel, then it becomes a film about life, death and our response to inevitable mortality - keep moving! In that respect it earns 3 stars, maybe 3-1/2. So, it is only so-so as a horror film but is quite good as an existential film about life, sex, and death. IMHO

This movie was a fail for me. Recently, Quentin T. praised the creator of this movie for the concept yet criticized him for failing to "take it there" and I would sadly have to agree. I thought the concept was awesome; that's why I was so eager to see it. However, the execution was just.not.there. There are no excuses even with it being a low budget horror flick. John Carpenter Halloween. I feel as though issues like this start with the writing. First off, on a basic level I didn't give a f about any of the characters. Wrong note to start off any story and not spend at least a brief amount of time developing the characters well enough for the audience to be invested. Second, the "supernatural entity" just wasn't relentless enough for me. I'm not even talking about kills here, or even necessarily explaining what it thing is (sometimes mystery is good, leave it to the imagination), it's just about creating tension and having an element of shock value to keep people on their seats. That wasn't there for me at ALL, as I spent most of the movie more interested in what was going on on Instagram. Maybe it would have been better had I seen it on the big screen or alone in the dark. At any rate, this one goes down as a "Cabin In the Woods" for me, a movie critics and horror fans love for the sake of getting something "different", but the substance is lacking and the scares were almost non-existent. For example (slight spoiler), there was a most ridiculous part in the beginning when the main character first deals with her curse in the classroom and she sees some geriatric old person in a hospital gown coming for her; she runs into the hallway and is terrified, but me I'm like really? You silly girl, you can easily just knock grandma out lol...I get what they were going for (vision - Exorcist 3), but the set up was all wrong. If this entity can take on whatever form it wishes to, why wouldn't it at least start off as something more intimidating to make her fear more believable? Overall, GREAT concept along the lines of a movie like Fallen, good camera shots and use of atmosphere, but subpar story and execution.
The plot was weak and was held together only by the beautiful cinematography. This didn't feel like a horror movie, at no point was I scared or on the edge of my seat. Complete waste of time.

Incredibly disturbing, It Follows is a creepy and atmospheric low-budget indie horror film. An allegory about STDs (in part), the story follows a young girl who, after having sex with her boyfriend, is stalked by a mysterious shapeshifting creature that can only be seen by those who've had sex with an infected person, and it can only be escaped from (for a time) by passing on the infection to another person through sex. Maika Monroe gives a strong performance that's nuanced and really shows her struggle to come to grips with her situation. However, the director makes some odd choices in creating a setting, as it comes off as a strange alternative reality with a mixture of futuristic and retro fashions and technologies (which is quite distracting). Additionally, the creature effects are rather grotesque; with the creature often appearing mangled and in various stages of nudity. A problematic film, It Follows delivers some effective scares, but the who and the what are so vague that the story ends up being rather unsatisfying.

So, I bored, it's nighttime in July, I go to see what's the best horror movies to see in 2015, and there are dozens to consider, some of which have been released already.. It Follows (2015) is actually not a bad independent film. This movie plays well on the old school eerie thrill horror, and has a really nice story line to go with that style. It's for sure low budget and it happen to pull off a really cool movie and I'm sure movie fans of this style of thriller/horror can enjoy it. The acting in this film was pretty well done and the graphics were even better than I would've thought.It Follows was put together with a small cast and an even smaller crew and yet pulled off a fairly well made horror story. It's a story that makes you think, and at the same time when ya think about it; well it's kind of funny. When I watched this film I started thinking about the old horror films like Halloween, Friday 13th, and others along this film styling; very well played. So if you're up for a fairly good thriller then check this one out; it'll surprise you.

Intriguingly different & creepy to a fault - however my praise for this ridiculously over-hyped movie ends there. Sure it's original, classy, arty (80s retro) & isn't revolved around desensitised murder & gore like so many horrors these days, but even so I thought it just didn't deliver. This is basically the ultimate urban legend come to life with an ingenious concept of some demonic relentless creature that pursues you after being "marked", which just so happens to be unprotected sex (lol), but I'm gonna be the one to call BS. This was seriously not that impressive & left me extremely underwhelmed. The creature could kick a hole in a door, smash a window then jump through it, lunge at someone & even swim but apparently skipped the lesson on running - where's the logic in that? Also what's the underlining message with the sex? Is the creature a giant metaphor for HIV/AIDS? Is this ultimately a hate movie against sluts? I'll also say, this movie relies waaay to heavily on the strange sinister soundtrack, if you took that away - it's not scary at all, just dumb. The more I think about it, the more I hate this film.

Tedious rather than thrilling, any tension the movie could've offered dissipated into the haze of seemingly self-indulgent, languid pacing. The actors are lethargic and mumble their words constantly-- that is, when they finally decide to break the dead air as the camera pans to and fro across the beautiful composition. Yes, the cinematography and sound design were superb-- it's just everything around it that turns out to be a dud. If you thought the first hour and 40 minutes were bad, stay tuned for the home stretch! It will make you feel things, finally -- not quite fear, unfortunately, more like disappointment, irritation, befuddlement as to how this movie has inspired many to wax poetic about how much a masterpiece it is.Close to the movie's end, we find a main character-- whose existence is, objectively, entirely unnecessary -- reading a few lines Dostoevsky out loud to her friends. I think that line alone should tell you whether you'd be the kind to like this movie or not. I'm firmly in the "not" pile. At the minimum, good movies-- good art-- make us feel the way they were set out to do-- fear, in this movie's case, rather than ire and tedium. 0/5 would not recommend.

My only problem would be that even though it's all about making suspense and tension, there's a fine line between that and making a movie too slow to be entertaining. It's also kind of lazy in my opinion to not explain in any way what the ghost was or what it wanted or how it started or anything. But after all, it does a great job at being disturbing. I noticed all the people I consider to be hipster love it, so I guess it's really a hipster-flick. If you're into the more mainstream stuff, you may be more likely to think this movie is quite slow and boring.

This is some very sad movie and too close to actual life to be entertaining...

I must sound like a broken record (or corrupted mp3 file) when I say that quality horror films are few and far between. A good horror film can keep you on the edge of your seat, thrilling you with clever scares or unnerving imagery. But any horror fan knows that in searching for a good horror film, you're going to see a lot of bad ones. Unfortunately, It Follows falls into the latter category. This film has a familiar beginning, though skillfully done: a teenage girl in red high heels bursts out of her house and runs out into the street then to her car. She runs, but doesn't get away. There is definite skill in the staging, and it was clear from the outset that this was aiming to be a low-key, subtle horror film, but something was amiss with that opening scene. The random teen girl being menaced in the first scene is not just a horror movie clich�, she, and those red high heels even more so, are a signifier that It Follows is a film that will emphasize style over substance. That would be forgivable if It Follows was engaging and scary. However, It Follows also emphasizes style over scares. The premise of this movie is intriguing and fresh. After having sex for the first time with her older boyfriend, young Jay (Maika Monroe) is attacked by him, drugged, and tied to a chair. He explains to her that he has passed to her a ghost that will follow her until it catches up with her and kills her. If it does, the presence will go back to following him. "It" can appear as anyone, even people she loves, and though it moves slowly it won't ever stop following her. There is nothing she can do to get rid of it, only pass it along to someone else. Though clearly aware of the allegorical implications -- STDs/AIDS, or adulthood/maturity, both of which amount to decay and death to a teenager -- the film never fully embraces this subtext, insisting that the theme is open to a broad interpretation.It Follows steers clear of some horror movie clich�s (there is almost no violence or blood), but falls into others (Jay's "nerdy" friend is characterized by big glasses and reading Dostoevsky's The Idiot). There are, of course, a few pop-up/startle scares. The climax is capped off with a creepy and memorable visual element. However, too many times I noted that while what I was seeing looked creepy, I wasn't actually creeped out or scared. Is that figure in the distance behind Jay "It" or just a normal person? Speed walking or a light jog in the opposite direction is all it would take to diffuse the situation. At certain points It Follows moves too slowly, and the non-scary scenes fail to build dread and danger. The "scare" scenes, or potentially scary scenes, are separated by scenes of Jay and her friends talking like they are adults on True Detective. They wax poetic about the line between the suburbs and the bad parts of town, but those ideas are not explored any further. The one consistently effective element of It Follows is the haunting synth score by Disasterpeace.I very much enjoy slow-burn horror films (Audition, John Carpenter's Halloween, and Val Lewton/Jacques Tourneur movies are some of my favorites). Because these films typically have low budgets, they avoid effects-heavy set pieces in favor of a grand, thrilling finale. The most successful examples make up for a lack of spectacle by building atmosphere and tension and creating full characters. It Follows clearly aims to be like the classic slow-burn horror films from the late 70s and early 80s, but ultimately it falls short in those crucial areas of mood and character and instead fills the time with dull teenagers talking to each other in rooms. Horror films can be flawed and still be successful. A good horror movie can have flimsy characters, plot holes, contrivances, it doesn't even have to make sense (I'm looking at you Suspiria and Hausu), but it must spook, unsettle, creep, disturb, or unnerve. It absolutely must scare and, even more importantly, entertain. It Follows did not have me anywhere near the edge of my seat. Instead I was slumped back, my mind wandering to memories of other horror movies.
Very boring movie, and not scary at all. I expected more from this movie but was let down.

Disappointing. I'm not a big horror fan but the glowing reviews for this film enticed me to give it a look. Stylish and unpredictable, yes. But the unique story completely fizzled out. I didn't want or expect a neat explanation for everything, but the ending left me feeling that the filmmakers couldn't figure out where to go next, so instead opted for an abupt ending, hoping critics would find that bold. It wasn't

Why did everybody like this movie? This was bizarre. A lot of bizarre logic and strange choices on the part of the characters. Also what was the ending? I dunno, this felt like a high budget student film.

Okay first of all, I trusted you Rotten Tomatoes. Secondly: I could never tell what was going on with the movie, it jumped way too much and frankly, I'm pretty sure I have whip lash from it. Third: what was up with the electronics around the pool? Seriously, what was that? Did you think that after shooting it in the head once that electrifying it or shooting it again would work? Lastly, I could totally jam to this soundtrack but it didn't really seem to work with what was going on. Over all, would not recommend and kind of wish I could give it less than half a star because I wasted my money and time on this.
It was a very original, unique, creepy, eerie, strange and suspenseful horror movie. I thought pretty good, but ending was really bad! Big disappointed! Actors were nice, but overrated...
I enjoyed the movie, it was suspenseful. But, the ending ruined the whole experience.

a different type of horror film no doubt, and one with a clear underlying theme it plays off of that everyone has experienced (your first sexual experience, how it affects you, and how you deal with the aftermath). believeable performances from a cast so young, but for me this film falls victim to it's own hype. watching on demand after it's initial theater run i had heard how unique the movie was for the horror genre and was expecting something great. what i saw was a decent film that does a good job setting a spooky aura for itself but a movie that had been HEAVILY influenced by other films in the genre to the point that some of the scenes were direct copies (i.e: the Faculty, Let the Right One In). not a bad film for a late night scare, but not as innovative as The Cabin in the Woods either.
absolutely stupid...it will definatly make you doubt the tomatoe meter and critics
Predictable, boring and too focused on monetizing a sequel instead of creating an interesting plot.

It Follows is not a scary movie in the least. A thought process on becoming an adult and std's maybe, but a scary movie it is not. The sexual monster has only two advantages really. Only people who have had it can see it and it never stops. The disadvantages are plenty though. It walks every where. It picks random people to be and usually they are naked. It can't open a locked door. While others not being able to see it helps it a lot, once you've had sex with someone then you both can see it. This means that you can get others help. What I think would have helped would be that you can no longer see it once you've passed it to another person. It's supposed to know who to pick to be, but that doesn't help if it decides to be naked. Most people aren't going to talk to a parent walking up to them naked. Which is another disadvantage is it can't talk. Usually you're taught at a young age not to talk to strangers and avoid people who frighten you. Someone who just walks towards you and won't say anything is in my book both. Then there is the huge flaw of it not being able to get into any place that a normal human couldn't do. I can't believe that I'm supposed to be afraid of something that can't get passed a locked door. Simple trap would be to lure it into a place with two exists and have a friend lock the door behind it while you lock the door in front of it. Now it's trapped till someone lets it out. Which if you picked a good spot could be never or at least well after you passed from old age. The last point is a flaw in the movie it seems. It gets shot, but gets back up and goes on as though nothing has happened. Then why is it afraid to get in the pool? If you say it's to kill her easier than it's doing a bad job.

Lets start by saying its a good premise...then lets go into saying that its completely destroyed and wasted. Most scenes just end in a fade, unresolved or really explained other then the standard "couldnt really think of a ending there". The now standard "lets put a 80s score on the film" is completely out of place and more distracting then not putting anything behind the scenes. The direction and acting is so lax that it just makes you angry to still be sitting there watching it going "For fucks sake, why are you fucking up this film?" It could be a case of a great film that was killed in post or by production, but whatever it is- its not the glory all that everyone talked about.

What a terrible movie. The pace is slow, the actors seem half asleep the whole time, and there are zero surprises once the premise is established. Not scary. Not sexy. VERY soft "R" rating. One of the most overrated horror movies I've seen in ages.
It was great in some aspects. It also drug along. I would have liked more back story on why this thing started following people. All in all, not a bad movie.

The movie jumps right into the story and sets you up for what is to come, it seems like the pace will be very frantic at first, but then everything really slows down, it does have the creepy shots and feel going for it that reminded me of "Halloween" from the scenery, the way it is shot and the music, but still seems slow and there is a major reason for that which I won't say. I was expecting something more I guess. I don't wanna say too much but it did not live up to the hype. It is worth watching because it is well made and a good horror flick is very rare these days. Good is about as high as I can praise it though.
I feel dumber after watching that.
Boring as hell. Overrated piece of shit. The music was the only thing good about the film.

It felt flat like zoomed in very close but still kept distance. It felt like the director really wanted to stand out with the way the movie is presented and its neat but not for everybody

This movie would be great if it weren't for the constant 70's & 80's references. I love horror films, (a bit to much), but I don't need to be reminded of horror's greatest ages. Enough with the synth sound track and rolled up jean jackets. I need something new! The story was good, the scene shots excellent-just bring things up to date a little. Not to much, I mean, I still like pop culture references, just not an entire movie built on them.

Why the hell are you freaking out over it? You could power walk away from it, no need to wreck your friend's car. This is one of the worst movies I have ever sat through.

The only reason i started a rotten tomatoes account, was to given this joke film 1/2 a star. All the critics giving this movie a high ratings, are either friends of the director or pretentious, academic hipters. Most probably both. The pool scene, at the end, was soooo bad, me and my friends were laughing our asses off.

Yes, the concept is original imagining teen sex as some type of horrible 1/2 naked shapeshifting demon that "follows" you around stalking your every move and there were a few creepy scenes. It's also hard to throw shade on hot teenagers running around in skimpy clothing....but I also don't think there was enough going on here to make this movie truly scary or that memorable. It's not all bad, but it's not that great either.

It Follows had the right creepy atmosphere, interesting cinematography (nothing truly unique, but shots not typically associated with a horror movie). However, It Follows didn't follow. The story falls flat, the characters are one note (with one particular character absolutely pointless), another falls prey to some horror tropes (running up the stairs, really?). There's something to be said for not much exposition , it still treats its audience as stupid with characters that make dumb decisions and a storyline that just doesn't work. I do applaud the film for its ambitious attempt, it's a lot different than most horror fare out there going for psychological thrills rather than blue and guts that most horror films go for nowad. I did enjoy the eerie atmosphere, the throwback imagery and setting, the ambiguity of the time setting, and the panning widescreen shots. I just wish the rest of the film could have executed better.

Did I really watch the same film as the rest of these critics? The basic premise and the actions of the characters made no logical sense (even for teens). It was not frightening, pedestrian, and only barely held our attention. Would not recommend.
An average horror movie at best. Creepy, but not enough blood and mayhem.
This movie was fucking boring. Slow, quiet, artsy, and weird for the sake of being weird. The music is cool though.

BORING! Just plain boring. Not much happens in this movie. It ends abruptly, and answers very little. Why is it following in the first place? And a person dies in the movie and the movies just goes on as if nothing actually happened. The acting is fine, but it's almost as though the directer has just one move in his bag: a slow, full, one shot, pan of the room or area. It's just about every scene that he does that shot. It gets old really quickly. I would have liked to have known why "it follows." And there is a scene in the movie that makes no sense at all: at some point the main character, who is trying to get rid of the problem, is on a beach and sees thee men in a boat. They show her swim towards them. Then, in the next scene, she and another boy are talking and the boy asks her why she doesn't just pass it along. She then ends up sleeping with that boy to pass it along. But it is implied that she slept with at least one of the men on the boat! So what was the point of that scene?

It's slow but its horrors is tense and nerve-racking at times. It Follows may have an eerily-horrifying concept but its dull dialogue and plain narrative defeats the clever scare-tactics the film offers and makes for a less-than-memorable frightening flick. 3/5

I was really eager to see It Follows, and I was ultimately disappointed. After a great opening, the movie dips into a lull and gets boring for a while until the scene where our lead character (Maika Monroe, who will next be in Independence Day: Resurgence) discovers "It". "It" is slow-moving and creepy, and "It" will kill her until she passes it on the next person. The movie is a great allegory for STDs, but then it dips again. And that becomes the movie's downfall. For all the gorgeous cinematography, the fascinating plot and the stunning set pieces as her and her friends battle "It", the movie keeps hitting dull patches. It's like a sputtering car; it stalls out several times over the running time before it reaches an unsatisfying ending. Perhaps it is one of those movies that need to be revisited again to catch new things, and I would watch it again. But for now, it's a slow burn thriller that fizzes out. It's also not scary at all, but it's got a promising idea for a sequel as well that I'd watch and hope is better.
Terrible and cheesy.

There is much to like about this film, but I just did not find it scary. It had some great moments but overall it just was a little boring and slow.

But the film I watched was shit and excruciating to watch and it ruined my day. Sitting there in the theater watching these long ugly scenes, with shit characters and smelly dialogue and this blaring synthesizer music that must have gone on for 60 mins straight; and looking across at my date who gives me a troubled smile that seems to say "You really fucked up with this film that you said was really good, we could be hanging at the pools right now"

Worst movie ever! Are you serious movie critics, to like this movie? The story is super dumb, there is no explanation, and it's just super stupid. And the worst is you guys thinking you're so cool cult, for liking such a dumb movie!

It Follows is quite possibly the most overrated movie of 2015 so far. It has a lack of suspense, the acting is poor, the female lead is such a dumb character, the soundtrack is cool but very misused and perhaps worst of all - it's not scary.

The movie's cinematics and editing were very interesting especially since it gave off a cheaper movie vibe. But in all it was interesting I would recommend this mostly to people who enjoy horror, as they would be the only ones who would like this.

Started off very good, with some real promise. The biggest problem I have with the movie is it made no attempt to explain anything or than 'Have sex and pass it on to someone else'. Part of what makes a movie scary or intense is the lore behind what is going on. Then, to add insult to injury, it just peters off. Im almost certain that there was no ending written for this movie.
I was bored throughout the entire movie! I don't think I've ever fallen asleep at a horror movie. First time for everything, I guess! And if you want a terrible ending, this is it! Enjoy!

Huge buzz around this movie. It had a good concept. Good horror films rely on suspense and tension, and this one has both elements aplenty. But it didnt have me up in arms and that ending though, really, come on bro.

I'm not sure why so many people are saying this movie is scary when it really isn't (unless you count the fact everyone owns a television from 1975 for some strange reason). The premise is really good but comes off completely dull and boring thanks to the director trying WAY too hard to make the movie feel like a late seventies movie. The result is a movie acted by dull characters that comes off way too dull. Horror from the 70s was slow but riveting. This was not. Adding the synth soundtrack also screamed that the director was trying too hard to make it a 70s movie. Thinking you can electrify a giant swimming pool with some house appliances also made me lose all respect for the characters intelligence level as well. Nobody with an IQ above 10 would think that would work.
PLEASE DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME- THIS IS THE SHITTIEST USE OF YOUR TIME- BELIEVE ME, DO YOURSELF A FAVOR AND DON'T WATCH IT.

Terrible... talk about low budget! Don't waste your time... I wasted an hour and 40 minutes of my time. Unbelievable how this got any good ratings at all. Slow, dull... not scary, and a terrible ending. Uggghhhh...

slower than trees talking. If that is David Robert Mitchel's idea of horror then he should take a look at the reflection of my sweaty ballsack in a bird birth on a hot summers eve then he might be a bit more qualified to write horror. The film should be renamed people sitting around looking sad. It's basically an STI with a grudge!

Writer and director David Robert Mitchell has a very simple, very scary idea: imagine being followed everywhere you go by a lone figure that's slowly but surely creeping towards you and that no-one else can see. Unfortunately, the idea doesn't quite work in practice, at least not as a feature length film. For most of its running time, It Follows is atmospheric, engrossing and often strikingly beautiful. But cheap jump scares and an absurd climax seriously undermine it, with Mitchell either unable or unwilling to commit fully to his premise. It's a shame - this could've been great.
I really missed the point with this one. Reviews were so stellar that I thought I was guaranteed to get into it. Nope! Strange pacing, and just an all around lack of spookiness!
A rather strange movie, interesting concept but that's about it... it never got exciting or interesting for me but still an okay watch.

What they did right: 1. Well done on the score. the music leaves nothing that will stay in your head, but fits the genre and the movie very nicely. 2. The acting was decent. Applause for them all doing a nice job coming off as normal people that react in believable ways. 3. Great shots and the general ambiance of the Michigan neighborhoods that I know so well really put a bullseye in the "Anytown USA" factor. Good attention to detail. Additional points for making me unable to date the film by mixing up the styles and technology. I liked that. 4. Successfully added suspense with minimal jump scares. This is the only thing that is making me understand the high reviews. People are just so desperate for true suspense in films, we'll take whatever we can get!What they did wrong:1. The ending. Really fell apart there. A lot of potential that ended flat and with messy, nondescript scenes. If they had just showed Paul walking in Tokyo or anywhere distant, that would have been more acceptable. Being that this is getting such good reviews, I'm sure we'll get that kind of scene in 2 or 3 or 6.2. The premise is provocative and alludes to the intrinsic basis in most horror films. That's neat. That's also about where that ends. Again, maybe having this STD from Hell is what's causing all the spine tingling, rave reviews. I don't know. To me, it's fairly dumb and classless. 3. The fear just isn't there for me. As I said, they managed a level of suspense rarely seen today, but the premise kills the fear factor. Just go bang someone young, horny and far away is the obvious solution. And the 1 death scene we got to view was far more disturbing than it was scary. 1. Just 1. So no, I'm not riding this train of praise for It Follows. I'm not fulfilled in any way after watching this movie. The best part about it was the realism of the shots and the environment. Other than that, this is Horror on Prozac.
The stupidest movie ever! No plot, suspense, storyline or intrigue whatsoever. Not worth your time at all!

It Follows? No... IT SUCKS!!! The only thing this movie follows is directions to the can. I am a big horror fan and I'm always searching for a decent scare. So I saw the movie based on the ratings. Not impressed. it is obvious, the makers of this production know how to bribe a critic. Unfortunately, we followed, IT won and that's the lembowski score.

I have absolutely no clue as to why this movie is reviewed so highly. I had a friend visiting from out of town and we went simply because of Rotten Tomatoes. This film was utterly boring, unscary and was one of the first times I have EVER considered asking for a refund. I also love all types of horror films and I am still seeing these scores and feel like I am in the twilight zone. Immediately upon the movie ending, another audience member got up and expressed his displeasure in what he had read on Apples as well. I truly don't get it.
Just wasted 2 hours of my life on this shite. I don't want to waste more explaining why

I honestly do not know how this movie got such a high rating as it did, because I found not being scary at all. I did, however, enjoy the concept behind "It," because of "Its" persistent following of the plagued teen.
Simply awful on all levels
Clearly influenced by Kurosawa Kyioshi's sounddesign and 80ies camera, but thanksfully it ends in a better story than most Kurosawa horrorpics.

One of the worse movies I have ever seen. It is more concern in being artsy than in creating interesting characters to care about. There are huge plot-holes on the origins of this thing and the climax was nonsensical and boring. The acting was mediocre and it seems that the cinematography was more interested in doing panoramic shots than showing us what was happening. I wouldn't recommend it to my worst enemy.
This movie was garbage. I expected more. It was literally just a stupid girl running away and having sex with people. Paul was the only good thing about this.

It Follows' inspiration garnered from John Carpenter's 1978 horror vision Halloween is simply obvious from the beginning with the portrayal of teenagers that are for the most part entirely normal and deal with the things the way the rest of us would. It's totally indie but also really polished. Unfortunately, I found that the awesome idea behind the film and the originality and attractiveness of the camera work are watered down by the pace and mood of the film that make it a tad boring at parts, predictable and a bit too subtle to even be acknowledged. It could've been amazing and one of the best horror films of the year, it isn't, but its definitely one of the most interesting.
Indie horror with an original concept to passing on the demons by screwing someone haha, how cool is that! Try watching cause 96% certified fresh on RT is no joke for a horror ;)

This movie is $7 and 2 hours of my life I will never get back. The best part of the movie was the previews. I don't know how in the world this got such a high rating, but you would be better off giving your money to a homeless person or getting a happy meal. Trust me, it would be a far better experience. The dialogue and acting is an abomination. And there is this girl who reads random quotes from a kindle in a clam shell. It has all the suddenness of a early eighty's horror film complete with bad synthetic music yet it carries no other qualities of a film. Just don't waste your money

I REALLY don't know what everyone was thinking when they gave this movie anything except for a warning NOT to waste your time! BAD ACTING, stupid script and the list could go on and on. There is nothing redeeming about this film, I literally can't think of one good thing to say about it, except for it's over and I never have to sit through that again!!! STAY AWAY!!!
Cinematography, composition and music are outstanding, but that's about it.

It Follows is a very original movie indeed but it's hard for me to put it in the horror category, because above all it's not, I repeat, It's not terrifying. In fact, for most of the time this movie is boring and sleepy. The original ideia comes by 20mns after the film starts, and it delivers with smartness and ability, but in my opinion, since we now know the premise the movie fails until the end. We have nothing new to see until the credits roll. We have some hight points here and there (I remember the beach and the pool scene) .. but man.. The inescapable sense does not exist. The director didnt give me that. I want some goosebumps. Stay only for the peculiarity. The Good: the pool scene... I guess.The Bad: this is not horror.. maybe thriller? Or a little YA sci-fi with independent execution? I don't know.The Ugly: err.. the new ground that the movie enters it's nice.
Very good little film. Nothing major. But glad I went.
Solid independent horror-ish thriller. Well worth watching.
very low-key horror about a STD (sexually transmitted demons). effective in its simplicity, there are no OOGA-BOOGA! jump scares, considering the target audience.

Strongly influenced by Nightmare on Elm Street, it's an able movie with some gorgeous long shots and strong suspense sequences. However at times, I felt the pacing was a bit uneven and an unnecessary love triangle annoyingly runs through the movie with little context.

Very chic packaging, as if aimed toward the teenager who thinks himself a little more elite than his friends who still hire gore horror from the video store. Very well filmed, the film looks like an indie at all time, sometimes desperately. But the entire angst it wants to convey is fake, artificial and underwhelming. And the soundtrack...

I watched this really creepy horror film last night. The menacing atmosphere built up to fever pitch. However, there was no proper plot or explanation as to what the 'thing' was or why it was following people. Then, there was an odd scene where a mother rapes her son - that didn't make any sense. But still worth watching for the moodiness of it all.

The trailer had me psyched for this movie but this was a huge let down. There were a lot of slow moments in this film with unnecessary dialogue. I had also expected "It" to be something we never saw. Instead "It" was just a series of slow walking gross looking people. And "It" turned out to be an STD. There was a lot of promise with the concept of this film but it was poorly done.
Basically a movie that tells you to not have sex, abstinence is the way, otherwise you might have the chance of getting this std.Best comedy movie of the year.

boring, pseudo-intellectual and hipster-style

This is the way that classic horror films were presented, and it is what makes it actually good....the premise is simple, but it is interesting enough to catch your attention and hold it throughout. it stays with you after the credits roll, and you will likely talk about it in the days after you see it....

Why have so many critics been duped by this film? Director David Robert Mitchell's horror movie drips with faux "Virgin Suicides" atmosphere and oozes "style" over substance, with the exception of the solid performances from his cast. The trendy synth music serves only to irritate with its hipster desperation and derails any chance his scenes have of creating terror. Stop filling your movies with so much fucking score, film makers of the modern age. The lack of clearly established rules by which the supernatural force (the "it" of the title) operates should have been an invitation for the director to create a story of compelling suspense and of the unexpected. Instead we have a poorly paced narrative (this film drags like a wounded dog) replete with frustratingly unanswered questions and inconsistencies. The "conclusion" illustrates that the key concept was only partially explored, and with a poverty of imagination and an over-investment in trendiness, it is ultimately squandered. Perhaps not a complete failure - there are a handful of effective scenes - but certainly a wasted opportunity and a genuine disappointment. The 96% rating at Rotten Tomatoes reminds me that this site is not always an accurate meter for determining what to see next.

There's stuff to like in terms of retro style (that soundtrack!) and the acting is more than competent (Maika Monroe is terrific, although the retro horror movie she made last year, The Guest, was way better) . But the dream-like time period annoyed the hell out of me, and bottom line: this is The Ring, but with sex instead of a video. And it's a good thing the monster never actually sneaks up on anyone or comes for them while they're sleeping.

Oh Puurlease, despite the plethora glowing critiques, the follwing is a B+ movie with better than average acting skills. The best thing about this film is the concept which is at least original but as for fright value, I'm afraid the following scrapes the very bottom of the bucket. Sexually transmitted followers are perhaps only slightly more uncomfortable than a virulent STD and with an equal horror factor than originates from below the belt.Saying that, if you have nothing else to do and it's raining outside, it's worth the watch, but not recommended for those on a first date.
very slow getting going, confusing and not even that scary.
Huge disappointment! This is a children's horror film.
Sexually transmitted disemons. Kinda sad the state of modern horror...a film that is merely decent like this is proclaimed to be the best American horror film in years.

Terribly boring, super slow burn. Not scary, better suited as a made for TV movie. It just amazes me how this film is so regarded by these critics. All this shows me is that no one should be paying attention to critics, they simply are trying to sabotage the Horror genre with art-house garbage. My advise to anyone who wants to see this film, wait till it's on free tv, it will put you to sleep. I am SHOCKED this is rated R, PG would suffice, they showed absolutely nothing, all implied.

I don't know where to start...! It is a pity to call it a horror movie. It has less suspense than Troll 2 and there is none scares. Even the 80-ish soundtrack can't make the atmosphere terrifying. The pace is far off - it feels more like a drama film than a horror/suspense film.The movie has a great potential, but it feels so empty.

While the film succeeds in spreading a sense of dread all through its running time, the multi-layered screenplay and below-par execution leave a lot to be desired. The climax as such is pretty much an arrow that misses its target by a mile. A decent effort for an indie horror.
Grossly overrated but points for its originality and atmospheric soundtrack. Maika Monroe is going to be a major star. You heard it here first.

Good and scary atmosphere with its psychological horror and a good premise... That's all. The story is horribly developed, it doesn't sustain itself and it doesn't even have an ending. If if this is the best that horror genre has to offer I think I'll keep avoiding it.
Naked dead people attacking other people... ? Meh!
The execution is not as interesting as its premise looked like.
if RT gave it a high rating chances are its crap. RT is glued to the standards of the past and absolutely not welcoming the talent of today.
Everything is good except the ending. What the hell could cost $2M making this movie?

I was bored throughout the entire film. Poorly acted. Horrible pacing and absolutely no payoff in the third act. Absolutely boring. I honestly can't imagine how this has impressed so many so-called critics....

I don't know if I was watching the same movie everyone else was watching, because to me this movie sucked! I'll admit I wasn't watching it to be intellectually stimulated, I was watching it to get the crap scared out of me (or at least for a good story). But this movie did no such thing! Call it what you want, but it was essentially a movie about a deadly Sexually Transmitted Poltergeist!!! It cant be in her mind or some clever play on a nightmare, solely because ****SPOILERS**** HER FRIENDS SAW IT (and by "IT" I mean the actions of the "ghost" because the could never actually see the "ghost" [If you can call it ghost, because it seemed to possess few ghostly qualities.]) Also there were waaaaay to many points in the movie where the story didn't add up, and it seemed to blatantly favor the main character (by this I mean, others in the movie have died in ways that she too was exposed to, and did the same as others did- yet her outcome was victorious...if that makes sense. I'm trying not to spoil the movie for people who still want to waste their time with this movie.) My point being I seen nothing "Artistic" or "Thought Provoking" about this movie, you have to try too hard to get real meaning from this movie. At best it can be used as a PSA for abstinence in Sex Ed class. If you disagree, please show me where I'm wrong. I am always more than happy to see things in more than one way, and I am most curious as to what 65% of you seen differently. I'm not here to troll the internet at 4am giving negative reviews on movies, I was just utterly shocked that so many of you gave a good review- my opinion had to be heard for the apparent few that felt like me.

Sorry, but this isn't original. It fits in the body horror genre and belongs along certain films like 'Teeth' and Cronenberg's 'Shivers'. So calling it original is for the naive or amateur horror buffs. Now as for the film it's pretty stupid and slow moving. I felt like a zombie while watching it.
